data.name: Bernaqua – Westside pool & spa
data.abstract: A unique building by star architect Daniel Libeskind houses around 2,000 square metres of water, with bathing fun for the whole family.
data.description:
Bernaqua, the largest adventure pool in the Bern-Mittelland region, offers plenty of opportunities for play, fun, sport and pure excitement. The adventure pool is a swimming pool of superlatives: various indoor and outdoor pools invite you to swim and relax. There are three giant water slides and a white water canyon, including the longest covered water slide in Switzerland. Separate children’s area and a charming bistro.

The Bernaqua wellness complex, an oasis of enjoyment and well-being, is a place where you can treat your body and soul to an intense experience that promotes inner balance and pure relaxation. Visitors can choose between a Roman-Irish bathing ritual, a sauna environment of unbelievable variety, a Kneipp therapy area, relaxing massages or beauty treatments.

Getting there: By suburban railway, tram or bus from Bern station to “Bern Brünnen Westside” or by car (the Bernaqua is located in the Westside shopping centre, exit 32 Bern Brünnen from the motorway).

additionalDescriptions.description: Life pulsates here! BERNEXPO: An area for maximum format diversity. With decades of experience and thanks to constant further development, BERNEXPO offers an all-in-one event venue that impresses at all levels, from the infrastructure to the range of services. Thanks to its wide range of facilities, the site is the ‘place to be’ for congresses, conferences, forums, trade fairs and festivals, making it the perfect stage for national and international events. Since April 2025, the site has been enriched by another beacon: a new 8,500 m2 building complex divided into a multifunctional hall (STAGE), foyer and congress centre (CUBE) offers maximum flexibility in a contemporary ambience, complemented by a hospitality area for catering.

data.name: Bern Cathedral
data.abstract: The Bern Münster Cathedral of St. Vincent is the most impressive late-Gothic building in the city and the largest and most important late medieval church in Switzerland. From this highest church tower in Switzerland you may admire a magnificent view.
data.description:
The three-aisled basilica without a transept towers above the roofs of the old town [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/old-city-of-bern/]is the largest religious building in Switzerland. Construction started in 1421 with builders working on this masterpiece over successive generations. The steeple was only completed in 1893.

From the church tower, you can enjoy a magnificent view over the city as far as the Bernese Mittelland and the snow-capped mountains of the Bernese Oberland.

An outstanding feature is the main portal, where you can admire the depiction of the Last judgment - the only image that was spared the iconoclasm of the Reformation. 344 steps above the entrance gets you to the lookout point: the 100-meter-high cathedral tower.

data.name: Bernese life on the River Aare
data.abstract: Adored by locals, the turquoise waters of the Aare provide the ultimate base for adventures of every kind.
data.description:
During the summer months, life for residents of Bern revolves around the waters of their beloved Aare. You can’t get closer to the river than sleeping on its banks and there are a whole host of places for tired water babies to rest their heads.

Bern Youth Hostel in the Marzili district, for example, boasts views directly over the Aare. Those who prefer to sleep outside can do so at Camping Eichholz: there’s no better feeling than opening the zip of your tent in the morning, poking your head outside and seeing the shimmering turquoise waters of the river there in front of you. And then there’s the Zollhaus. Located on the Nydeggbrücke bridge, this bijou hotel boasts views over the Aare, the Bear Park and Bern’s Old Town.

data.name: Berneuse – Panoramic views from Kuklos
data.abstract: Left beside the Dents du Midi you catch a glimpse of the majestic Mont Blanc, while looking right the Diablerets and mighty Matterhorn – and between the Col du Pillon and Col des Mosses you spy the Eiger. The mountain above Leysin and Aigle is famous for the “Kuklos” revolving restaurant – from the Greek for “circle” or “rotation”.
data.description:
The round glass construction, 750m above Vaud’s Leysin holiday resort, (Kuklos in Greek meaning "Ring") takes on its mountain neighbour’s Tour d'Aï and Tour de Mayen.The seemingly futuristic panorama restaurant revolves under the power of self-produced solar energy, achieving full-circle in 90 minutes.

The Berneuse is accessible by cable car from Leysin; there are successive projects to extend the cog railway from Aigle – where trains to Les Diablerets and Ollon/Champéry depart – all the way to the Berneuse. 

Hikes to the mountain lakes, Le Temeley alpine cheese-making dairy, mountain-bike routes, challenging via ferrata and interesting renewable energy trail.
Altitude: 2045m 
Accessibility: 
Train to Aigle, steep cog-railway trip up to Leysin-Feydey, on foot to the valley station (10 minutes), gondola railway to the Berneuse 
View: Part of the Bernese Alps, Vaud Alps, over the Rhone Valley to the Dents du Midi, Lake Geneva and Jura 
Attractions: Modern glass construction with revolving restaurant "Renewable Energy" trail, via ferrata Tour d'Aï (K4) 
Culinary aspects: Revolving restaurant 250 places, self-service restaurant 120 places, terrace 180 places 
Overnight stays: Berneuse: none; Refuge de Mayen sleeping in straw 
Groups: Club Berneuse, facilities for seminars, meetings & private gatherings for up to 50 people, private terrace 
Winter: Winter sports region Leysin 
Special comments: One and only revolving restaurant in western Switzerland

data.name: Bernina Express
data.abstract: This panoramic train connects the north of Europe to its south – right through the UNESCO World Heritage site of Rhaetian Railway, passing by glaciers on its way down to palm trees.
data.description:
Crossing the Alps in the Bernina Express certainly is one of the most spectacular ways to do it. Along the way, the Bernina Express rolls over the 65-metre-high Landwasser Viaduct, the signature structure of the Rhaetian Railway and the UNESCO World Heritage site. Altogether the train passes through 55 tunnels and over 196 bridges on its way from Chur to Tirano. Travellers are treated to marvellous sights during their journey, like the Montebello curve with a view of the Bernina massif, the Morteratsch glacier, the three lakes Lej Pitschen, Lej Nair and Lago Bianco, the Alp Grüm and the Brusio Circular Viaduct. The journey can be extended aboard the Bernina Express Bus from Tirano to Lugano from February to November (daily in summer).

FACTS BERNINA EXPRESS (TRAIN)
Route: Chur/St. Moritz – Tirano (Italy) or vice versa Distance: 144 km Duration: 4 h - 4 h 30 min FACTS BERNINA EXPRESS BUS
Route: Tirano (Italy) – Lugano or vice versa Distance: 90 km Duration: 3 h EXCURSION TIPS
 * Arosa Railway – from Chur to Arosa within one hour. On just 26 km, the train negotiates an amazing 1000 m in altitude
 * Railway Museum Albula – over 600 exhibits from more than 100 years of railway history, e.g. one of the last «Crocodile»-Locomotives
 * Gandria – a picturesque little town at the foot of Monte Bré
 * Monte San Salvatore – one of the most beautiful scenic outposts along Lake Lugano
 * Palm Express – rich-in-contrast, roughly four-hour postbus drive from Lugano to St. Moritz
 * Mountain excursion Diavolezza [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/diavolezza-1/]

FOOD & BEVERAGES
 * The Bernina Express minibar offers delicious snacks and refreshing beverages
 * The train does not feature a dining car. The guests spend their lunchtime in the Italian town of Tirano

TIMETABLE
 * Summer and winter timetable panoramic trains [https://tickets.rhb.ch/en/pages/bernina-express]
 * Timetable regular scheduled service [http://www.sbb.ch/en/home.html]

TICKET
This route is fully covered by the Swiss Travel Pass (Flex) and GA travelcard.
Book public transport tickets [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/planning/transport-accommodation/tickets-public-transport/]

RESERVATION
Apart from a valid ticket, a seat reservation is required on both train and bus. In addition, a reservation surcharge applies:

RESERVATION SURCHARGE BERNINA EXPRESS (TRAIN)
Short route: St. Moritz- Tirano / Tirano - St. Moritz
15 Dec 2024 – 13 Dec 2025
CHF 28
Long route: Chur – Tirano / Tirano - Chur
Low season: 15 Dec 2024 – 14 May 2025 / 27 Oct – 13 Dec 2025 CHF 32 Long route: Chur – Tirano / Tirano - Chur 
Main season: 15 May – 26 Oct 2025 CHF 36
RESERVATION SURCHARGE BERNINA EXPRESS BUS
Low season: 15 Dec 2024 – 14 May 2025 / 27 Oct – 13 Dec 2025 CHF 14 Main season: 15 May – 26 Oct 2025 CHF 16
Go to reservations [https://tickets.rhb.ch/en/pages/bernina-express]BROCHURE
Fascinating and comprehensive information around the Bernina Express, featuring highlights and relevant facts and figures, can be downloaded here:
PDF brochure [https://issuu.com/stnet/docs/sw20091.1006.2001.3064?fr=xKAE9_zMzMw]

data.name: Bern, just follow your nose
data.description: Sniffing, snuffling, smelling: The guests are taking a tour of the city, literally following their noses, learning more about the history and the scents of Bern. Afterwards, with the help of an expert, they create their own Bernese scent that they can take home.

data.name: Bernhard Russi Run
data.abstract: Experienced skiers really come into their own on the Gemsstock above Andermatt with its high-Alpine terrain, magnificent panorama and challenging slopes. The highlight is the descent on the Bernhard Russi Run to Gurschen.
data.description:
In the 1970s, Bernhard Russi achieved legendary success in the Olympic Winter Games and World Championships. Although this former ski racer is now a world-renowned ski run architect, he did not create the Bernhard Russi Run in Andermatt himself. Rather, this was the place where he practiced his swings in his younger years. Later, his home village named the challenging slopes in his honour. The route runs from the summit of the Gemsstock, with its panoramic view, steeply down to the cable car middle station at Gurschen. 
Starting point: Am Gemsstock (2963 m a.s.l.) 

Accessibility of starting point: mountain train 

Destination: Gurschenalp (2210 m a.s.l.) 

Length: 4.3km 

Altitude difference: 950 Meter 

Level of difficulty: difficult (normal slope) 

Food and beverages: at the end

data.name: Bernese Oberland – Railway
data.abstract: The Bernese Oberland valley railroad was opened in 1890 and has been been electrified since 1914. It connects Interlaken (Interlaken East) with Grin with Grindelwald and Lauterbrunnen. Besides serving the resort towns, it also enables access to the world famous Jungfraujoch-Top of Europe.
data.description:
As a rule two trains coupled together ride up to Zweilütschinen where they are separated. One train travels to Grindelwald, the other one to Lauterbrunnen. 

The Bernese Oberland valley train presents itself as a modern shuttle that opens up the tourism centers in the Eiger, Mönch & Jungfrau Region.

data.name: Berneuse-Leysin
data.abstract: The valley descent from the Berneuse to Leysin affords a breathtaking panorama. The run is suitable for a wide range of performance levels and those who find the steep sections too difficult can easily detour along the blue-marked sections.
data.description:
The Berneuse is one of the most beautiful vantage points in western Switzerland. Here you can enjoy a magnificent view of the plain of the Rhone and as far as the Lake Geneva basin and to the Dents du Midi. During your descent to Leysin, the Diablerets massif in the east is almost constantly before you. The piste takes you down into the valley in wide arcs through alternating open and wooded terrain. Experienced skiers may use the shortcut options in the form of the steeper sections marked in red and black. 
Starting point: Berneuse (2048 m a.s.l.) 

Accessibility of starting point: mountain train 

Destination: Leysin (1350 m a.s.l.) 

Length: 8.5km 

Altitude difference: 700 Meter 

Level of difficulty: medium (normal slope) 

Food and beverages: at the start

address.name: Télé Leysin-Col des Mosses-La Lécherette SA

data.name: Bernina Herb Express
data.abstract: A journey on the Bernina Herb Express to Le Prese is a chance for passengers to experience the UNESCO World Heritage Site up close and immerse themselves in the world of herbs in Valposchiavo.
data.description:
Choose from various starting points and enjoy the trip to Le Prese, where you can enjoy a lunch that is 100% sourced in Valposchiavo and go on a tour of the herb fields and production facility of Raselli Erboristeria Biologica. Afterwards, make your way back to where you started out from.


More information [https://www.rhb.ch/en/leisure-travel-and-excursions/relaxation-enjoyment/graubuenden-gourmet-trip/bernina-kraeuter-express]

data.name: BärenPark (Bern Bear Park)
data.abstract: The Bern bear pit is an attraction that is known far beyond the borders of Switzerland. Since 2009, the Bern bears have primarily had a modern, 6,000 square meter park at their disposal, which they reach through a tunnel - the BärenPark.
data.description:
Since 1513 bears have been at home in Bern; until 1857 in the town itself, then in the bear pit, and since 2009 in the new and spacious Bärenpark.

The site on the banks of the Aare stretches from the former bear pit opposite the Old Town [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/old-city-of-bern/]to the river. Thanks to a lift, the entire facility is now wheelchair-friendly. The “Bear Pit”, which still exists and has been listed as a federal cultural asset of national significance, remains at the bears' disposal. 

Guests can go on a tour of the old bear pit as well as the new bear park. They get to see the new park with its green hilly terrain, which includes caves and the "Bear Bath" in the Aare River [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/aare/]. Guided tours can also be booked during which you learn plenty of interesting things concerning the history of the Bärenpark - a peek behind the scenes.

data.name: Sporty Bern - City Tour by scooter
data.abstract: When was the last time you rode a scooter? Well now you’ve got the chance!
data.description: Glide at your own pace along the Aare River through the old Matte District, then take the Marzili cable-railway to the upper city. From there, you’ll ride to the historical sites, perhaps take a refreshing break beneath the fountains on Parliament Square (Bundesplatz) and listen to the stories and anecdotes told by the guides.

image.name: Sporty Bern - City Tour by scooter

data.name: Experience Bernese music up close and personal
data.abstract: Many famous Swiss bands hail from Bern. Music has a long tradition in Switzerland's capital.
data.description:
Alexander Balajev and Lukas Hasler, drummer and bassist with the band Troubas Kater, are equally passionate about music and the micro brewing business. Bern is known for its dialect music and beer with character - like the Schuum beer which the two musicians brew. The best way to experience both is at a Troubas Kater concert.

More information and tour data can be found here [https://www.troubaskater.ch].

data.name: Experience Bernese neighbourhood restaurants like a local
data.abstract: The neighbourhoods of Bern are as diverse as their restaurants, and there are quite a few of them in the federal capital. You can really get a true sense of the typical Bernese lifestyle by visiting one of Bern's cosy neighbourhood pubs.
data.description:
Whether in a restaurant, a bar or a snug café, connoisseurs will find much to love in Bern. Guests not only enjoy fine drinks and excellent cuisine in one of the numerous neighbourhoods pubs, they also get to experience the authentic neighbourhood life of the city of Bern up close.

Here [https://www.bern.com/en/neighbourhood-places] is a selection of unique restaurants to suit every taste.

data.name: St. Bernard Express
data.abstract: Starting point for the St. Bernard Express is in Martigny in the canton of Valais.
data.description:
Route: Martigny - Orsières - Grand St-Bernard

Just like the Mont-Blanc Express, the St. Bernard Express also has its point of origin in Martigny. Pass through the Val d'Entremont to Orsières, from where a bus will take you to Champex-Lac, La Fouly or if it is summer (June to end of September) to the hospice on the Grand St. Bernard Pass. There visit the legendary kennels where the dogs of the same name are bred, as well as the small local museum to view the Roman artifacts found here.

data.name: Escape Game Bern
data.abstract: New and exclusive in Switzerland: the first mobile Team Escape Game for up to 200 participants!
data.description:
The problem to be solved is:
Computer virus T1 is threatening to paralyze all communication systems. The necessary anti-virus software is on a missing data carrier which needs to be found. To do so, participants will need to solve cool riddles and challenging tasks. In this game every participant will realise what the word teamwork really means.
The only clue at the beginning:
Participants must try to open the mystic box to get closer to their goal. Having solved one riddle, the next one is already waiting to be figured out. The remaining time until the computer virus becomes active is counted down without mercy! An exciting race against time begins.

data.name: BLS RegioExpress Bern - Luzern
data.abstract: The BLS RegioExpress will bring you to one of Switzerland's most original areas.
data.description:
Route: 
Bern - Konolfingen - Langnau - Trubschachen - Schüpfheim - Wolhusen - Lucerne

The BLS RegioExpress trains run between Bern and Lucerne at hourly intervals. Travel time: approx. 1h30.

The route from Bern to Lucerne through the Emmental Valley and Entlebuch is a secret tip among Swiss train routes. Typical for the Emmental are the farmhouses with deep roofs that dot the rolling hills. Cows grazing on the lush green meadows supply the milk for the world-famous Emmental cheese with the large holes. Visitors who continue their journey through Entlebuch traverse Switzerland’s first UNESCO Biosphere Reserve. Fascinating moorlands and a multifaceted flora and fauna characterize this award-winning landscape. It is worthwhile to make stops en route: in Schüpfheim the PostBus “Panorama Route Express” awaits visitors and takes them through the Lammschlucht, a canyon, to Sörenberg and further on via the panoramic route to Giswil, where one can get train connections to Lucerne and Interlaken. The Kambly experience in Trubschachen, which lets visitors immerse themselves with all their senses into the secrets of pastry art, is worth a visit as well. Those who prefer exotic plants will be in their element in the Tropical House Wolhusen with its variety of tropical plants and crops.
No seat reservations possible.

data.name: Christmas in Bern
data.abstract: A visit to Bern in December is particularly magical thanks to the many Christmas markets and pop-ups. The numerous Advent experiences are within walking distance in Bern's UNESCO-listed Old Town. And many villages around Bern also offer enchanting markets and experiences during the Advent season.
data.description:
During the Advent season, the scent of gingerbread, roasted almonds and mulled wine wafts through the festively decorated streets of Bern's old town. If you follow them, you will find great Christmas markets and pop-ups in various squares. From traditional to artisanal to a paradise for foodies: Each Christmas market impresses with its very own character. 

The UNESCO World Heritage Site with its old town houses dating from the 15th to 17th centuries and Bern Minster - the highest church tower in Switzerland - provides a fantastic and unique backdrop. Even away from the markets, a Christmas shopping spree is a special experience thanks to the 6 kilometers of arcades and the typical Bernese vaulted cellars. 

For those who like a picture-book Christmas, we recommend a trip to other parts of the Bern region. From the romantic Christmas market in Huttwil and the lovingly decorated chalets at the Kambly Experience to what is probably the largest nativity scene in the Central Plateau - Christmas lovers can also experience wonderful atmospheres in the Gantrisch Nature Park, the Emmental, Oberaargau and Laupen.

 [https://www.bern.com/de/weihnachten]More information: Christmas in Bern [www.bern.com/weihnachten]

data.name: Prison Tower Bern
data.description: The Käfigturm was the city's second western gateway. The tower was built between 1256 and 1344, served as a prison between 1641 and 1643 and retained that function until 1897. The clock was installed in 1691.

data.name: Criss-crossing Bern by bike
data.abstract: Get an authentic feel for Switzerland’s capital by bike, just like a local.
data.description:
Whether cycling through Breitsch (Breitenrain) or Lorraine, along Länggasse or down to the Marzili – you can reach everywhere in Bern fast and easily by bike. And if you don’t have your own bike, you can rent one from the PubliBike bike-sharing network: bikes and e-bikes are standing at the ready at a number of stations across the city. Simply download the PubliBike app and off you go!

Bikesharing in Bern [http://www.bern.com/en/detail/bikesharing-in-bern]

The most beautiful bike routes in and around Bern [https://www.bern.com/de/velo/velo-routen]

data.name: Weekly market Bern
data.abstract: Weekly market Bern
data.description:
Every Tuesday and Saturday from May to October the Waisenplatz, Bärenplatz, Bundesplatz and the adjacent side streets feature a market selling fruit, vegetables and flowers. From May to October, the market is held every day except on Sunday on Bärenplatz. Enjoy the lively atmosphere on a leisurely and tasty stroll past the many stalls.
Further information and opening hours:

data.name: Münster (Cathedral) Bern
data.abstract: Begun in 1421, Bern's Cathedral took 150 years to complete, and was erected entirely by volunteers. The cathedral was built for the purpose of housing a bishop, but Protestantism reached Bern before its bishop did. The cathedral represents the last major work of late Gothic architecture in Europe.
data.description: The interior architecture of the Münster attests to the cathedral's construction during the city's conversion from Catholicism to Protestantism. The choir's religious symbols are strongly Catholic; coats of arms on the ceiling's keystones come from Protestant times; empty statuary niches reveal religious artworks that were removed and destroyed at the transition. Other notable design elements include unusual black ceiling flourishes, added after the Gothic had gone out of fashion; the massive granite altar taken from Lausanne Cathedral; and the 15th-century Last Judgment sculpture over the main portal. Protestant church leaders left the carving intact because of its justice theme. 234 human figures, from high and low ranks, religious leaders including the pope and lay people, are represented. Some of each group head to heaven, and some to hell.

data.name: Sanetsch – between Bern and Valais
data.abstract: Those arriving from the Rhone Valley come by car or take the Postbus up to the top of the pass - and on to the Sanetschsee lake - and from Gsteig you can get to the lake by public transport with the power station’s gondola railway.
data.description:
The Sanetsch Pass region, between Wildhorn and Diablerets is source of the Saane. The pass from the Rhone Valley to Saanenland was used by both traders and troups at war during the Middle Ages, whereas today you see bikeres or hikers on the very same stretch. An easy hiking route leads around the lake, and mountain hikers certainly get their fill on a path from the Glacier 3000 and Quille du Diable via Cabanne de Prarochet to the Sanetsch Pass and gondola railway (back to Gsteig).

And be sure not to miss out on a visit to the "Auberge du Sanetsch" to meet a special person and enjoy the sweet side of life with some very tasty culinary treats.
––– Closed this summer!
Altitude: 2062m 
Accessibility: 
Train to Zweisimmen, change of transport direction Gstaad or MOB from Montreux to Gstaad, Postbus to Gsteig; or train from Aigle to Les Diablerets and Postbus over the Pillon Pass to Gsteig; on foot to Innergsteig (25 minutes) and gondola rail to the Sanetsch Lake
In the case of crowds during peak season, tickets are issued for the valley descent at the mountain station (restaurant close by) 
View: Over Gstaad and Saanenland, Sanetsch Pass and surrounding rock walls, glimpse of the de Tsanfleuron glacier (from the pass) 
Attractions: Round path alongside the Sanetsch Lake, Saane source, hikes from the Glacier 300 over the Lapis (glacier foreland) to the Santesch Pass 
Culinary aspects: Auberge du Sanetsch by Maurice Luyet, own Valais wines 
Overnight stays: Very special romantic rooms, courtesy of your hostess and personal furnishing, as well as group accommodation 
Groups: Diverse facilities, terrace with seating for up to 200 people 
Winter: closed 
Special comments: Own museum, own bakery, own wines, own chapel and last but not least own mountain wellness!

data.name: Photo Spot Bernina Glaciers
data.abstract: Wildly romantic, sunny and sheltered: Pontresina is nestled amongst mountains – a place for leisure as well as recreation. Arguably the best vantage point is the world-famous Montebello hairpin bend, at the point where the Bernina section of the Rhaetian Railway crosses the road. You can see the tallest peaks of the Eastern Alps behind the Morteratsch Glacier, including Piz Bernina (4,049 m), Piz Palü (3,901 m), Piz Roseg (3,937 m) and Bellavista. Fancy cooling down a little? The glacier trail from Morteratsch station takes you to where the ice is eternal.
data.description:
Address:
Plauns (street to Morteratsch) 
7504 Pontresina

Parking: 
Car park on the right-hand side of the road

Footpath: 
0 minutes

data.name: Hammam & Spa Oktogon Bern
data.abstract: Pure oriental relaxation.
data.description:
The oriental spa represents the latest magnificent manifestation of a tradition spanning two millennia. The bathing ritual in the hamam is based on the step-by-step warming and cleansing of the body.
Housed in the Oktogon, an octagonal building dating back to the 19th century and the first gas boiler in the city, this hamam in Bern seeks to keep alive the spirit of oriental bathing. The Hammam & Spa Oktogon Bern offers a unique spa experience on four floors.

data.name: Farm Olympics in Bern
data.abstract: A totally Swiss experience! Who's going to win Olympic gold in the cow milking or blowpipe competition?
data.description: The group can have its very own Olympic Games on one of many farms – all within 20 minutes of Bern. Choose the type and number of games based on your group's interests and budget.

data.name: Old City of Bern
data.abstract: Thanks to its well-preserved medieval townscape, the Old Town of Bern was entered onto UNESCO’s listing of World Heritage Sites in 1983.
data.description:
UNESCO World Cultural Heritage Site 
The capital of Switzerland has many charms. Its quaint old town is framed by the Aare Riverand offers spectacular views of the Alps.

With its 6 km of limestone buildings andmedieval arcades,its Renaissance fountainswith colorful figures, and its beautiful cathedral [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/bern-cathedral/]surrounded by picturesque rooftops, Bern [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/bern/], founded in 1191, is truly a gem of medievalarchitecture in Europe.

data.name: Golf in the Bernese Oberland region
data.abstract: The majestic Eiger, Mönch and Jungfrau summits, crystal-clear lakes and picturesque villages of the Bernese Oberland present a natural paradise for all nature lovers.
data.description:
The unique surroundings in which the golfing greens of the region are discovered are something not to be missed! With Thun and Interlaken additionally inviting you to shop in elegant boutiques surrounded by stunning lake and mountain scenery.GOLF COURSES
9-hole golf course:

Golf Club Thunersee, Thun [http://www.golfthunersee.ch/]

18-hole golf courses: 

Golfclub Interlaken-Unterseen, Interlaken [http://www.interlakengolf.ch/ ]
[http://www.golfmountain.ch/golfmountain/golfplatz-und-driving-range/ ]

data.name: Photo Spot San Bernardino
data.abstract: The San Bernardino mountain pass, built between 1817 and 1823, was the first road for wheeled vehicles over a Grisons pass. It connected Bellinzona with Chur or – on a larger scope – the port of Genoa with southern Germany. Some decades ago, the route was carefully restored. Set in the magnificent mountain scenery between Hinterrhein and San Bernardino, examples of impressive road building skills from the 19th century can still be admired today.
data.description:
Address:
San Bernardino mountain pass, 6565 San Bernardino

Footpath: 
1 minute

Please note that the Photo-Spot is stored during the winter months.

data.name: Golf in the Bern region
data.abstract: Berne is a rambling region, correspondingly presenting a wealth of diversity. Here, Middle-Age villages, vast unspoilt stretches of land and an abundance of very different landscapes fascinate one and all.
data.description:
Each and every region is in itself worth a visit, whether the hilly Emmental landscapes, extensive Mittelland crop growing areas, Gantrisch Nature Park, pre-Alps and of course famous Gstaad. Golfing greens are spread throughout the region to the delight of all – and as crowning finish to any Berne visit, Berne’s Old Town (UNESCO World Heritage Site) is simply a must! GOLF COURSES

18-hole golf courses: 

Golfclub Emmental, Oberburg [http://www.golfemmental.ch/] 
Golfpark Moossee, Münchenbuchsee [http://www.golfparks.ch/de/golfparks/golfpark/moossee] 
Golfclub Gstaad-Saanenland, Gstaad [http://www.golfclubgstaad.ch] 
Golfclub Entfelden, Oberentfelden [http://www.aarau-west.ch/] 
Golf Club Heidental, Stüsslingen [http://www.golfheidental.ch/] 
Golfclub Weid Hauenstein, Hauenstein [http://www.golf-hauenstein.ch/] 

9-hole golf courses: 

Golf Club Aaretal, Kiesen [http://www.golfclubaaretal.ch/de/index.asp] 
Golf Club Schinznach Bad, Schinznach Bad [http://www.bad-schinznach.ch/sport/golf]

data.name: Follow your nose in Bern
data.abstract: Be transported to the world of fragrances in the beautiful Old Town of Bern. Literally follow your nose on a guided tour and learn more about the history and the smells of the City.
data.description: From sandstone and liquorice to the aroma of cocoa - Bern boasts a host of unique scents with a thrilling past. After the tour you will create your very own Bern fragrance at the "art of scent" perfume studio run by perfume specialist Brigitte Witschi. You will be able to take your fragrance home with you.

data.name: Discover the Museum Quarter Bern
data.abstract: Culture, history, science, art and innovation come together in the Museum Quarter Bern and inspire with a lively interplay of impressions and emotions.
data.description:
The Museum Quarter guides you through a lively universe. It tells stories, stores cultural assets, organises exhibitions and events. Here, learning becomes pleasure, entertainment becomes education and art becomes experience. The place is not just a destination to visit, but a world full of experiences, encounters and inspiration that invites you to join in - time and time again. With over 500,000 visitors, it is the largest cultural centre in Switzerland.

In the centre of Bern, embedded in historical buildings and contemporary architecture, it is also a place of retreat and relaxation with the museum garden. A place where you can feel at ease and be enchanted. No matter how far you have travelled. Discover the diverse offerings of the eleven institutions that are part of this vibrant network The Museum Quarter [https://www.mqb.ch/en].

With the Museum Quarter Pass [https://www.mqb.ch/en/pracitcal-information], you can experience the diversity of the Museum Quarter Bern for five months.

data.name: Crossing the Great St. Bernard Hill
data.abstract: The thousand-year-old hospice in Great St. Bernard is the point of departure for this hike.
data.description:
The dogs descended from the legendary Barry welcome visitors in their usual friendly manner. The museum and the precious hospice are a gentle start, before going in the general direction of Italy for a few kilometres and returning to Switzerland via the three mirror-like lakes offering spectacular reflections of the surrounding mountains. The descent into the village of La Fouly provides a touch of colour as the wild flowers spring up in Val Ferret. Tasting alpine cheeses and the lively atmosphere in the village restaurants will revive you a little and prepare you for your return journey.

How to get there:
Take the TMR SA bus for the Great St. Bernard hill. The return leg is by TMR SA bus from La Fouly, which will take you back to the starting point in Orsieres. Orsieres is on the Great St. Bernard Express line.

data.name: Foxtrail – Puzzle fun in the Bernese Oberland
data.abstract: In the Bernese Oberland, the scavenger hunt is available in Thun, on the Ballenberg and in Emmental. In these uniquely beautiful surroundings, the fox ensures that chasers are never bored. Whether in the midst of ancient buildings at the Swiss Open-Air Museum, with a spectacular view of the castle in Thun, or looking for the locomotive Emma – there’s something for everyone on these Foxtrails.
data.description: The fox has laid its trails. Secret messages, hidden clues and many tricky and perplexing challenges show you the way from one stop to the next. You are out on the trail by yourself and never know what’s waiting in store for you – even people familiar with the region are bound to discover new things. The Foxtrail takes you through towns and countryside on foot and using various means of transport. The trails last between 1.5 and 4.5 hours. All you’ll need is good shoes and a mobile phone per group in case you need to call the hotline. Pricing depends on your age and the length of the trail. Simply book online through the website, print the starting instructions and enjoy solving the puzzles!

data.name: Guided beer tour through the Bernese beer culture
data.abstract: Team up with a seasoned beer sommelier and embark on a beer fact-finding tour: learn some interesting insights and anecdotes that are bound to impress people.
data.description: For starters, why does beer from a bottle taste better than it does in a glass? Find out this and a whole lot more on a beer tour – and not only in theory. You’ll learn all about beer and how it is produced at four locations, in two pub breweries and selected beer bars in Bern’s old town. It goes without say-ing that you'll also have the chance to partake in some professional beer tasting.

data.name: Adventure rides aboard the Rhaetian Railway / Bernina Express
data.abstract: The city of Chur and the Rhaetian Railway simply go hand in hand. The RhB provides public rail transport from Chur for the SBB and its red trains take you along stunning routes to your destination.
data.description:
Chur is the starting point for the famous adventure rides aboard the Bernina and Glacier Express. Every inch of this rail network is one big treat, no matter whether you are on the Alpine crossing from glacier ice to Gelato al Limone or on the route from St. Moritz to Zermatt over 291 bridges and through 91 tunnels, or whether you are taking a day trip or a multi-day trip, or whether you are riding on an express or a regular train.

The Rhaetian Railway also regularly schedules trips aboard special trains. These may include a steam train ride or a culinary expedition.

data.name: Make your own fondue at the Bernese Christmas Market
data.abstract: At the Bernese Christmas Market, the Platzhirsch restaurant offers a do-it-yourself fondue. Choose your own ingredients, fork them up, and relish them with a nice cup of mulled wine. A truly memorable experience!
data.description: The Platzhirsch provides an international step-by-step fondue tutorial for the inexperienced, for tourists or for those just looking for a good time. Equipped with a shoulder bag containing bread and a fork, and a fondue table with all the trimmings, guests can enjoy preparing their own fondue.

data.name: Swin Golf against the backdrop of the Bernese Alps
data.abstract: Swin-golf is different from classic golf because it takes place on natural prairies, with a single club that has three faces and a softer, larger ball. A quick introduction is all that is required to master the basics of this new sport.
data.description: The 9-hole Swin Golf course in Nax offers a breathtaking view of the Bernese Alps and offers the perfect conditions for familiarizing onself with this outdoor sport. There is no age limit. Therefore, Swin Golf can be played with the entire family, friends or colleagues. The adjacent restaurant caters to the pleasures of the palate.

data.name: 12 beer experiences in the beer capital of Bern
data.abstract: From a brewing course to the “ZAPF! Craft Beer Festival” and the Bern brewery walk, these 12 experiences are the perfect way to immerse yourself in Bern’s beer culture.
data.description: Beer is the lifeblood of Bern. You get a real sense of this as you walk though the capital, as well as the opportunity to experience it on almost every corner. Try your hand at brewing in the museum, go on a beer walk or head off on a beer tour of the city to discover all the secrets behind Bern’s beloved amber nectar. Other options include “beer versus wine” evenings, a visit to the Brauerei Felsenau brewery or quite simply enjoying a beer up a mountain in the Gantrisch Nature Park. Cheers!

image.name: Bern
image.copyrightHolder: Partner image for editorial and touristic use / digitalemassarbeit.ch / Bern Welcome

data.name: The "something for everyone" toboggan run in the Bernese Oberland
data.abstract: This downhill run, divided into two sections, takes tobogganers to the beautiful village of Gsteig. From there you can catch the post bus back to Gstaad.
data.description:
Berghaus Wispile – Chrinetritt (1st section) 
The hike and toboggan ride to the Chrinetritt takes about 40 minutes and follows a beautiful panoramic route. Once there, the rapid downhill run commences. 

Chrinetritt – Satteleggli – Gsteig (2nd section) 
The upper part of this trail is moderate to difficult, while the lower section is less steep. Once you have finished, it is only a few minutes’ walk to Gsteig. From here, catch the post bus back to the Wispile valley station.
Starting point: Mountain hut Wispile (1,915 m.a.s.l.)
Accessibility from starting point: Cable car
Finishing point: Gsteig (1,189 m.a.s.l.)
Altitude difference: 600 metres
Length: 7.5 kilometres
Level of difficulty: difficult
Toboggan hire onsite: yes
Illuminated for night sledging: no
Option to eat: at the start, along the way, and at the finish

data.name: Marzili Lido
data.abstract: The most popular open air bathing spot in Bern. As with all other public baths in the town of Bern, the Marzilibad is completely free. The separate “Paradiesli” and “Männerbad” areas allow men and women to sunbathe unclothed.
data.description:
The Marzili (also known as the Marzer) has a paddling pool for younger guests and a sports pool with 8 x 50m lanes, a non-swimmer pool and a diving pool with 1m and 3m diving platforms. There are also 10,000 square metres of open space for relaxing in.

If you visit the city in summer, sooner or later you will be recommended a visit to the “most beautiful river baths in Europe” with a view of the Swiss Parliament House and minster – free of charge, please note.

The first baths opened here in 1782, when admission cost 5 cents. In 1822, an oval swimming pool with a timbered wall was added, fed by the River Aare. The green area was added in 1957 and in 1968 the 50-metre pool was built.

Without a doubt, the most special thing about the Marzili is the opportunity to swim in the open water of the River Aare (but you must be a strong swimmer to do so!). There are several spots around the pool and along the river with steps and handrails for you to enter the water. Guests change in the baths and then make their way upriver to the entry point of their choice.

Getting there: By train to Bern, then preferably on foot – the lido is located directly beneath the Parliament House, Marzilibahn or by car (parking spaces are signposted “Marzilibad” and a charge is payable).

data.name: Adventure Park Ropetech
data.abstract: The Adventure Park Ropetech near Thunplatz is a fixed-rope park established among the natural tree population of the Bernese Dählhölzli Forest.
data.description: On six Parcours for diverse skill levels, visitors can experience a new perspective of the forest from a height of 4 to 18 meters. Visitors are not likely to forget this mix of adventure, thrills and nature. With its 1,500 meters of routes, the Adventure Park in Bern is one of Switzerland's largest fixed-rope parks. For tiny tots as of 4 years of age, three diverse children’s parcours close to the ground, as well as Powerfan with spine-chilling free-fall from a 30-meter height for the more courageous entertain kids here.

data.name: Marzilibahn funicular
data.abstract: Since 1885, this funicular has been the fastest route from Bern railway station to the Aare and the Marzili-Bad lido. It now carries a million passengers per year, departing every few minutes on its one-minute journey.
data.description:
The shortest public funicular in Europe. Until 1974 the Marzilibahn was a water ballast funicular. At the top, a tank under the passenger cabin was filled with 3,500 litres of water drawn from the Stadtbach – the excess weight of the car then pulled the other car upwards. You can see one of the historic wooden water ballast wagons not far from the bottom station – another is on display in the Swiss Museum of Transport in Lucerne. 

Today, the fire engine red train that connects Bern’s city centre (300 metres from Bahnhofplatz) to the residential districts on the Aare is powered by electricity. 

Altitude: 539 metres 
How to get there: 
300-metre walk from Bern railway station to Kleine Schanze next to Parliament House, funicular down to the Marzili district 
Views: From the Parliament House terrace down to the Aare and the Schwellenmätteli and Marzili districts, on a clear day as far as the Bernese Alps with the Jungfrau 
Attractions: (accessible by Marzilibahn funicular) Marzili lido, swimming in the River Aare with views of Parliament House 
Food and drink: Restaurant Marzer near the Marzilibahn, Restaurant Marzilibrücke, restaurants in Schwellenmätteli 
Accommodation: City of Bern 
Groups: The youth hostel (double and multi-bed rooms) near the bottom station of the Marzilibahn has a large hall with a stage 
Special comments: You can see one of the historic wooden water ballast wagons not far from the bottom station – another is on display in the Swiss Museum of Transport in Lucerne.

data.name: City tour by scooter
data.abstract: Sporty Bern.
data.description:
Glide at your own pace along the Aare River through the old Matte District, then take the Marzili cable railway to the upper city. 

From there, you’ll ride to the historical sites, perhaps take a refreshing break beneath the fountains on Parliament Square (Bundesplatz) and listen to the stories and anecdotes told by the guides. 

Combined with an aperitif at the Altes Tramdepot restaurant, this tour will be an unforgettable event.

data.name: Enjoying the River Aare
data.abstract: Walk along the riverbanks, enjoy an ice cream and sample some culture – you don’t have to be a water baby to enjoy the Aare in Bern.
data.description: The famous “Bernese attitude to life” is hard to put into words; it’s something you have to experience for yourself. And where better to do this than on the banks of the Aare? Take a stroll along the river and soak up the relaxing and friendly atmosphere for which Bern is famous. If you prefer to live life at a faster pace, why not try a jog along the river instead? Or simply sit and watch the world go by on the terrace at Casa Novo. Located on the banks of the river, this restaurant serves GaultMillau-awarded cuisine. And for dessert, look no further than where the locals themselves go: Gelateria di Berna. This ice cream parlour is universally considered to be the home of the best ice cream in the whole of Switzerland

data.name: iPad City Treasure Hunt with tabevents
data.abstract: The high-tech team challenge combines adventure and the spirit of discovery. Divided into groups the participants embark on an interactive journey through the city of Bern.
data.description: With this high-tech treasure hunt, which was rewarded with the German Tourism Award, the participants not only get to know the city very well but also are challenged to show teamwork and cooperation.

data.name: Kubus
data.abstract: This extension to the "Bernisches Historisches Museum" (Historical Museum) is sure to amaze with its exhibition hall sunk into the ground and its significant extension programme.
data.description:
In 2009, after the three years it took to build the Kubus, the museum now had enough space to properly store and attractively display its collection. This imposing building was designed by the Biel architectural firm, :mlzd, with the company prevailing against the other 15 competitors in the architectural competition that had attracted a total of 120 applications. 

The extension plan included a 1200m2 exhibition hall with walk-in roof terrace, floors allocated to storerooms and office space for the "Bernisches Historisches Museum" as well as offices and a library with reading room for the city archives. The exhibition hall is sunk into the ground: There is an area on the roof that is accessible from the park and the entrance hall. To the rear, the office building is sealed off in a fortress-like fashion.

data.name: Le ciel
data.abstract: Finest clubbing on cloud nine. Diverse events and parties ensure heavenly party fun in this newest club in Bern.
data.description:
With international top DJ Bob Sinclair the first star sparkled at this club's party sky during the opening in 2010. Other popular party labels like "Adore" and "All eyez on me" followed as well as parties with DJs from the renowned clubs Mansion Miami and VIP Room Paris.

When it comes to sound the Le Ciel has a wide range of beats. Mainly house and R'n'B as well as party tunes - the right thing for the right event.

A dancefloor of over 250 square meters on the main floor is the center of flashy club nights. Dancing, drinking, flirting - just partying.

If you prefer an exclusive treat, book a table in the VIP-lounge and let yourself be spoiled by a private servant. If you prefer an exclusive treat, book a table in the VIP-lounge and let yourself be spoiled by a private servant.

data.name: PROGR - Cultural Production Centre
data.abstract: More than 150 artists from every discipline work in this studio in the heart of Bern, from graphic designers to choreographers and filmmakers. People meet here to produce art, but also to drink coffee, sell pictures and talk about books.
data.description:
PROGR takes its unusual name from the schoolhouse it once was: in 2004, the premises of the Progymnasium – also known as the “Proger” - became vacant and were set up for temporary use as a cultural centre. For years it was unclear exactly what would become of the historic building in Bern's Old Town: at one point it was to house the contemporary art department of the Bern Museum of Fine Arts, then there were plans for medical practices and treatment rooms. It was only in 2009, after an emotional public vote, that culture won through: the PROGR Foundation received the planning and building rights to the property for 30 years.

Today, artists from a variety of disciplines work in about 70 rooms – all just five minutes from the main station. The ground floor is open to the public and a meeting place for culture lovers. Appropriately, the staff room is now a café bar that also serves as a bookshop and gallery. At weekends, the former gymnasium with its cosy green courtyard hosts parties and concerts by performers including Bernese icons such as Stiller Has and the Kummerbuben.

data.name: Bundeshaus
data.abstract: The Swiss Parliament House is the seat of one of the world’s first modern democracies and is located in the capital, Bern. Although the Bundeshaus is Switzerland’s seat of government, it also offers a range of entertainment and event opportunities for locals and visitors alike.
data.description:
The Parliament was built in accordance with the plans of the Architect H. Auer. It was completed in 1902. In the central hall, under the cupola between the two assembly rooms, there are numerous symbolic depictions of Swiss history [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/planning/about-switzerland/history-of-switzerland/]. After undergoing extensive renovations, the seat of Swiss government has been gleaming with new resplendence since May 2008. Guided tours are available. 

Bern [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/bern/]was chosen as the Federal Capital of Switzerland in 1848. However, the Bundeshaus, with its terrace and the Bundesplatz [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/bundesplatz-parliament-square/]square, is much more than just the seat of the Swiss government. It is also a crowd-puller, photo opportunity and a meeting place for young and old. On the "1848 - Bern as capital city" tour, you will learn more about the 150-year history of the Federal Capital. 

The Parliament House also opens its doors to regular guided tours of the premises. Outside the building there is also much to see: The terrace is an inviting place to sit as you enjoy the views of the Marzili [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/marzili-lido/]public baths, the Aare [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/aare/], and the Gurten [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/gurten-views-over-berne-and-the-alps/], Bern’s iconic local mountain. Of interest are the Bundesplatz square, the fountain in summer, and a light show and ice rink in winter. There is also a variety of events and the typical Bernese markets Zibelemärit [/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=master%3A%7BC7EB95D0-2656-4EDA-B1A3-03B4D3906048%7D%40en](onion market) and Christmas markets [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/winter/christmas/], etc.).

data.name: Westside shopping centre
data.abstract: With Westside star architect Daniel Libeskind created a new landmark for Bern. The leisure and shopping center combines shopping, swimming and movie theaters as one unique experience.
data.description:
The world famous architect, Daniel Libeskind, created in Bern with Westside an architectural highlight and his first leisure and shopping center worldwide.

The spacious leisure and shopping center Westside is an exciting place to be with international flair. Westside is the new city gate to Bern, a stylish place for everyone to shop, dwell, enjoy and relax. 

Westside offers something for everyone visiting: 54 stores, 13 restaurants, 11 theaters, the 4-star hotel holiday Inn and the Bernaqua - Water Park and Spa, a premium wellness and swimming park.

data.name: Rose Garden
data.abstract: The Rose Garden is a mecca for flower lovers and a great place to unwind. It features a restaurant in a prime location and a wonderful view of Bern.
data.description:
The Rose Garden is a large park with a wonderful view of the Old Town [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/old-city-of-bern/]and Aare Loop. The park is home to 220 different types of roses, 200 types of irises and moor beds with 28 different types of rhododendrons.

From 1765 to 1877 the Rose Garden served as a cemetery. Since 1913 the Rose Garden has been a public park resplendent with the rich beauty of flowers and a pond. From 1956 to 1962 the park was redesigned, introducing rhododendrons and azaleas as well as an iris garden.

A pavilion and reading garden provide a place to relax. The restaurant Rosengarten is a great place to while away the time, and it offers a view of the rows of houses in the Old Town.

data.name: Stroll through the Old Town
data.abstract: Bern's Old Town on the Aare peninsula was declared a UNESCO World Cultural Heritage Site in 1983. The Swiss capital is a magnificent example of mediaeval European urban architecture, mellowed by an enchantingly relaxed pace of life.
data.description:
City tour “Eating out in old Bern”
Rosina, Sinner, a Bern patrician, takes the group on a culinary journey through the city of Bern of yesteryear. She goes on a shopping trip. Meat, bread and spices are on her list. On the way to the market, butcher and baker, she reveals a recipe or two and shares stories about eating and drinking habits in times past. In Zunfthaus zu Metzgern – which is perhaps the oldest restaurant in Bern – Rosina Sinner then asks guests to take a seat and enjoy the dishes from way back when.
City tour [https://www.bern.com/de/detail/zu-tisch-im-alten-bern]
The "Old Town Stroll" through the Swiss capital takes in the late-Gothic Minster, the Federal Parliament, the Cage Tower and the famous Zytglogge clock tower, Bern's oldest city gate dating from the 13th century.

As guests stroll through the unique and historic Old Town on this 90-minute tour, they hear a summary of facts as well as tales both cheerful and serious about past and present.

data.name: Volver
data.abstract: Volver, right by the Bern town hall, is not only a café and a bar, but also a restaurant, and sometimes even a club or concert venue. Maybe soon to be your new “nest” in Bern.
data.description:
Good news for all migratory birds, early birds, night owls and other typical Bernese “birds”: Bern now has a cosy new nest with a Mediterranean atmosphere in the heart of the Old Town at the Town Tall Square. 

Give a chirp as you go past the Volver BarTapasCafé or sit comfortably and chatter to your heart’s content. There is always something nice to peck at, and tasty snacks are served right up until closing time. 

"Volver" means “return” in Spanish. To make sure that you do just that, we have plenty of culinary gems from Spain and Switzerland to delight and surprise you with, and new tapas specials each week.

data.name: Beck Glatz Confiseur
data.abstract: The Mandelbärli (almond bear) - is a typical souvenir of Bern - and a specialty of Beck Glatz Confiseur. In addition the Confiserie serves the very best baked goods, sandwiches and coffee.
data.description:
The legendary Mandelbärli is a shop specialty and the perfect gift from Bern. In addition to classic vanilla there are many other flavors ranging from chocolate to honey to lemon. A very bearable treat.

The Beck Glatz Confiseur café will treat you with hot coffee drinks such as latte macchiato or cappuccino and will help you start your day with coffee or espresso - of course also available to go.

Several times per day the confectionery team makes 20 different types of fresh and tasty sandwiches. At all sales stands you will find constantly new creations according to our motto: fresh, healthy, seasonal - and just for you!

data.name: Sassal Mason viewpoint
data.abstract: At first glance the high alpine region around the Bernina Pass looks barren, yet it boasts a wealth of alpine flora.
data.description:
Begin of tour:Ospizio BerninaPoint of arrival:Alp GrümAccess starting point:Rhaetian RailwayAccess point of arrival:Rhaetian RailwayPhysical fitness:mediumDifficulty:mediumHiking time:2h45Length:10 kmSeason:June to September
You can see this for yourself on the path along the Lago Bianco to the Sassal Mason (2355 m), with its splendid panorama of the Palü glacier and as far as the Val Poschiavo. All along the way there are tempting restaurants to spend a while in, at the Ospizio Bernina, in Sassal Mason, at the Belvedere and on the Alp Grüm.

data.name: Excursion: The Emmental
data.abstract: The city of Bern lies just west of the lovely, hilly region of the Emmental.
data.description: The verdant hills form the foothills of the Bernese Alps, and are dissected by the River Emme. Train travel through the valley is peaceful, serene and scenic. Make time for a stop at a local cheese shop, to purchase the valley's trademark Emmentaler cheese (the Swiss cheese with the holes).

data.name: Tour of the Zytglogge (Clock Tower)
data.abstract: The Zytglogge (clock tower): Visit the landmark of Bern's Old Town and experience the history and mechanics of the tower on a guided tour.
data.description:
Every hour on the hour, a fascinating spectacle takes place in Bern: the medieval puppet show of the Zytglogge (clock tower) begins. The dancing bear train, the cheeky jester and the crowing rooster are a delight for young and old alike.

If you would like to know more about the significance of the statues, the mechanics and the history of the Zytglogge (clock tower), you can take part in the one-hour guided tour.

The tour is a special experience, and not just because of the unique atmosphere inside the tower. Time seems to have stood still here many years ago, while heavy wooden beams and solid stone walls take guests on a journey into the past. In the historic rooms, only the steady ticking of the medieval mechanism accompanies visitors through history.

Also part of the tour: the ascent to the viewing platform. A wonderful panoramic view over the alleyways and rooftops of the old town and the green surroundings awaits.

Further information and booking:Zytglogge tour [http://www.bern.com/en/detail/berns-clock-tower-zytglogge]

image.name: Bern, Zytglogge
image.copyrightHolder: ST image for editorial and touristic use / Switzerland Tourism / Silvano Zeiter

data.name: Eiger Run
data.abstract: Rumour has it that the Eiger Run is one of the most attractive and well-groomed toboggan runs in the Bernese Oberland...
data.description:
…But, what we do know for certain is that the Eiger Run is Switzerland’s most spectacular tobogganing descent. The route ends up along the foot of the Eiger and passes directly under the legendary North Face. The illuminated trail at night makes nighttime sledging a truly memorable experience.
Starting point: Alpiglen (1,616 m.a.s.l.)
Accessibility of starting point: Cog railway
Finishing point: Brandegg (1,500 m.a.s.l.)
Altitude difference: 116 metres
Length: 3 kilometres
Level of difficulty: medium
Toboggan hire onsite: yes
Illuminated for night sledging: yes
Option to eat: along the way, and at the finish

data.name: Six kilometres of arcades
data.abstract: Thanks to its six kilometres of arcades, Bern is in effect home to one of the longest covered shopping promenades in Europe.
data.description: This has its benefits not only in rainy weather, but also in high summer, when the shade is cool and pleasant. Speciality stores, boutiques, galleries and emporia filled with curiosities all make for happy window shopping. Bern’s museums, meanwhile, ensure that the city has plenty to inspire culture fans, too.

data.name: ViaFrancigena - Between adventure and worship
data.abstract: Route: Pontarlier (F) - Lausanne - St-Maurice - Martigny - Great St. Bernard - Aosta (I)
data.description: In 990, Sigeric “the Serious”, archbishop of Canterbury travelled back to his English home town from Rome and made a note of the stops along the way in his diary. Today, the route is known as ViaFrancigena, a European culture route. The priory church of Romainmôtier in the Jura Vaudois, the cathedral of Lausanne and St-Maurice abbey in the Valais are sacred, spiritual highlights along the route whilst the climb to the Great St. Bernhard is one of the most spectacular stages from a scenic point of view.

data.name: Alp Grüm
data.abstract: Alp Grüm is a station on the Bernina line of the Rhaetian Railway and offers a unique view of the Val Poschiavo and the Palü Glacier. Its car-free, remote location makes it a popular destination for hikers, rail travelers and nature lovers.
data.description:
Alp Grüm lies at an altitude of 2,091 m and can only be reached by Rhaetian Railway or on foot. The Bernina Railway, part of the UNESCO World Heritage Site, connects St. Moritz with Tirano and stops here for an impressive panoramic view. Hiking trails lead from Ospizio Bernina or Cavaglia to the station.

The region around Alp Grüm is characterized by a high alpine landscape with views of the Palü glacier and the Val Poschiavo. Hikers appreciate the path to Lago Palü or the route into the valley. The Alp Grüm restaurant serves regional specialties and a sun terrace with far-reaching views.

data.name: Ricola Herb Garden
data.abstract: The Kandertal valley is set in the unique mountain scenery of the Bernese Oberland. You will find some of Switzerland’s most impressive hiking routes here, around the Oeschinen and Blausee lakes, the Gemmi and the Blüemlisalp.
data.description:
Kandersteg is home to one of the six Ricola herb gardens and this is located right next to the historic Ruedihus inn. The Alpine scenery invites you to linger and explore the fascinating world of herbs. Here in the herb garden you will find all 13 herbs used in making the Ricola herb drops. Feel free to touch and smell the herbs!

INFORMATION

The Ricola Herb Garden in Kandersteg is open from June to September. 
Admission is free.

Contact and travel information:

data.name: Planplatten alpen tower
data.abstract: The Sustenhorn, Grimsel region and Finsteraarhorn on the one side, with Lake Brienz, the Rothorn and Jura in the far distance on the other. A beautiful vantage point to the east of the Bernese Oberland.
data.description:
The Hasliberg stretches from the Brünig Pass as far as Reuti – to where a cable car from Meiringen ascends, with the gondola railway continuing on to Bidmi, Mägisalp and Planplatten.

The panoramic Alpen Tower restaurant is the hallmark of this mountain, from where hikers set foot on attractive hikes on highland paths to the Käserstatt or Melchsee Frutt region, on to the Engstlenalp and up and over the Joch Pass to Engelberg. 
Altitude: 2245m 
Accessibility: 
Train to Meiringen, on foot through the village (15 minutes), cable car to Hasliberg Reuti; or train to the Brünig Pass, Posbus to Hasliberg Reuti, and by gondola rail (3 sections, 1x change of transport) to the Planplatten (Alpen tower) 
View: Titlis, Engstlental valley, Sustenhorn, Grimsel region, Finsteraarhorn, Wetterhorn and Lake Brienz 
Attractions: Vantage point with views of 401 mountain summits, Muggestutz children’s adventure world, high and flat mooreland trail 
Culinary aspects: Tower bar with 360° panorama views, Panplatten Sunday brunches and Käserstatt 
Overnight stays: No accommodation on the Planplatten, Käserstatt multi-bed rooms and dormitory 
Groups: Alpen tower: Panorama restaurant 150 seats, sun terrace 200 seats and suitable for groups
Käserstatt: 250 places, Stübli 70 places, terrace 150 seating places 
Winter: Winter sports region Meiringen-Hasliberg 
Special comments: Accessible from Meiringen or the Brünig Pass

data.name: Moléson – a popular destination in the Fribourg Pre-Alps
data.abstract: It’s no wonder that the Moléson has a special place in the hearts of Fribourg’s citizens: the journey up to the panoramic peak is an adventure in itself. Once you reach the summit, you are greeted by wonderful 360° panoramic views of the Gruyère Pre-Alps and the Bernese and Valais Alps.
data.description:
The Gruyère region is known not only for the small town of Gruyères [https://www.myswitzerland.com/de-ch/reiseziele/gruyeres-greyerz/] and the world-famous cheese that bears its name, but also for the Moléson mountain, which can be seen from miles around. Two modern cable cars with panoramic windows connect the village of Moléson-sur-Gruyères [https://www.myswitzerland.com/de-ch/reiseziele/moleson-sur-gruyeres/] with the Pre-Alpine peak. When you arrive at 2,002 metres above sea level, the whole of western Switzerland is at your feet: from Lake Geneva to the famous peaks of the Bernese Oberland, from Mont Blanc and the Jura to the Three Lakes region.

In addition to the magnificent panorama, a visit to Moléson is particularly worthwhile because of the wide range of leisure activities on offer:

SUMMER
In summer, adventurers can experience the thrill of a rapid ride down the summer toboggan run or try their skills in a downhill cart. A host of hiking trails invite visitors to explore the area on foot. Those with a head for heights can attempt one of the two via ferrata routes or enjoy the spectacular views on the Trematta ridge hike [https://www.myswitzerland.com/de-ch/erlebnisse/route/sentier-de-la-crete-du-moleson/]. The demonstration cheese dairy [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/moleson-alpine-cheese-dairy/]is well worth a visit, where you can learn what life was like for the cowherds in days gone by. Every day at 10 a.m. (May to September), the cheesemaker lifts his cheese from the copper vat and talks about his work.

WINTER
In winter, the Moléson is a paradise for tobogganers, skiers and snowboarders. There is also plenty on offer for ski tourers and freeriders.

Tip: If you’re staying in Moléson, the Passe-Moléson [https://www.moleson.ch/en/passe-moleson/] is well worth getting. This all-inclusive pass covers cable cars, the toboggan run, downhill carts and much more besides!



Altitude 2,002m Getting there Train from Bulle or Montbovon to Gruyères, bus to Moléson-sur-Gruyères, funicular to Plan-Francey and cable car to the Moléson summit Opening hours The opening hours [https://www.moleson.ch/horaires/]of the funicular and gondola vary depending on the season and assume good weather conditions.
Magic Pass The Magic Pass [https://www.magicpass.ch/en/] is valid for the funicular and the gondola.
Food and drink The Le Sommet summit restaurant serves typical Gruyère specialities such as fondue moitié-moitié (half Gruyère, half Vacherin) or meringues with double cream Accommodation Accommodation options in Moléson [https://www.fribourgregion.ch/en/la-gruyere/alpine-huts/?r=7408&attr_58=1] Groups Theatre/conference hall in Moléson-sur-Gruyères: 120 people Special comments Saturdays and Sundays evening trips from 6 p.m. until 11 p.m. to Le Sommet upper station and back down to Moléson-sur-Gruyères (summer season). Evening trips are available in winter to Plan-Francey middle station and back down to Moléson-sur-Gruyères.

data.name: Photo Spot Niesen
data.abstract: Between the Simmen and Kander valleys, Niesen rises like a pyramid, providing visitors with a view of Spiez Bay, probably the most beautiful in Europe. In addition to being home to the world’s longest staircase (11,674 steps), a funicular covering 1,943 metres (6,375 ft) altitude difference leads to Niesen Kulm, including its mountain lodge, which was founded in 1856. From here it is only a short walk to the 2,362-metre-high summit platform (7,750 ft) with an impressive 360° panorama view, covering the Bernese Alps from lakes Thun and Brienz to the Jura.
data.description:
Address: 
Niesen Kulm, 3711 Mülenen

Parking: 
Niesenbahn valley station. 140 available parking spots. Subject to a charge. CHF 5 (up to 5 hours), full day up to 24 h: CHF 8, season parking permit for CHF 60 per vehicle.

Ascent:
Every 30 minutes from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. Evening timetable: Wed (from July) /Fri/Sat, individual tickets, group tickets

Footpath: >10 minutes

Please note that the photo spot is not accessible during the winter months.

data.name: Jegenstorf Castle
data.abstract: In the heart of Switzerland, just a stone’s throw from the capital Bern and set amid a paradisiacal park, lies Baroque Castle Jegenstorf. Inside, the former Bernese patrician country estate boasts all kinds of treasures and gems, with tales to take visitors of all ages on a magical journey back in time.
data.description:
Albrecht Friedrich von Erlach had the old castle converted into an elegant summer residence in the French Baroque style in 1720. Jegenstorf Castle has been open to the public since 1936. At the end of the Second World War, it served as the command post for General Guisan and, in 1954, the imperial residence for Haile Selassie, the Ethiopian state guest. 

The interior features an impressive wealth of finest-quality Baroque, Rococo and Classical-period furnishings. Special mention should be made of the largest exhibition of Swiss tiled stoves from the 18th century, invaluable pieces of furniture from the marquetry workshops of celebrated cabinetmakers and the most extensive collection of Bernese portraits. 

A range of walks are possible in the extensive parklands surrounding the castle. Discover the Baroque carp pond, orangery, the oldest plane trees in the canton, ProSpecieRara apple orchard and the historic bathhouse that is today home to the Castle Café.
Alle Veranstaltungen im Schloss Jegenstorf [http://www.schloss-jegenstorf.ch/web/veranstaltungen.php]

data.name: Parsenn
data.abstract: The Parsenn funicular climbs the Weissfluhjoch in two sections much like an express train. With the Davos landscape below us, the view extends as far as Piz Kesch, the Bernina and 60 kilometres to the south.
data.description:
Since the funicular first opened over 80 years ago, the Parsenn has been the classic ski mountain with its mix of endless wide pistes and stylish, traditional mountain huts. The Parsenn Derby, the oldest ski race in Switzerland, is held here every year. The ski area is accessible from Davos via the Parsenn funicular and from Klosters via the Gotschnabahn cable car. 

The Parsenn is not just a winter destination, however! It is also an attractive summer hiking area, with 700 kilometres of marked hiking, themed and panoramic trails. And mountain bikers can look forward to fantastic bike tours and adrenaline-charged freeride trails like the spectacular Gotschna Freeride Piste from Gotschnaboden.

Altitude: 2,693 metres 
How to get there: 
Rhaetian Railway to Davos Dorf, two-stage Parsenn funicular to the Weissfluhjoch; or from Klosters Platz via the Gotschnabahn cable car to the Gotschnagrat ridge 
Views: Via Davos to the Dischma and Sertig valleys, Graubünden Alpine panorama from the Silvretta region over Piz Linard to Piz Kesch, to the Bernina Chain and the Tinzenhorn, which resembles the Matterhorn 
Attractions: Hiking trails, bike tours, freerides, tandem paragliding 
Food and drink: Höhenweg and Weissfluhjoch Parsenn mountain restaurants, Weissfluhgipfel restaurant (winter only), Berggasthaus Parsennhütte and Berggasthaus Gotschnagrat mountain inns, old and new Schwendi mountain guesthouses, Berghaus Schifer mountain inn, Berghütte Chesetta mountain hut, Franzl’s Blockhütte Erezsäss 
Accommodation: Many of the mountain inns have rooms and multi-bed dormitories (not on the Weissfluhjoch, except in winter in the Igloo Village) 
Groups: By arrangement in the mountain inns 
Winter: Parsenn winter sports arena 
Special comments: The history of the Parsenn funicular is shown in pictures in the Davos Winter Sports Museum.
