data.name: Chillfood
data.abstract: When outdoor kitchens pop up in quarries, on riverbanks or even on railway tracks and a menu is conjured up using flames, embers and regional ingredients, then “Chillfood” can’t be far away.
data.description:
Here, preparing a simple menu becomes an authentic (outdoor) adventure. In addition to the unique experience itself, you will be reminded once again that less is often more. Take a step back from your hectic daily routine and enter a world of soothing simplicity and a “chilled state”.

Chillfood means cooking organic ingredients from local farmers over firewood from the Bernese forest, “chilling” on furniture made of locally-sourced wood – painted with non-toxic paints – and washing up with water from the water treatment plant and phosphate-free washing-up liquids. Chillfood embraces sustainable catering, transport, building materials, waste disposal and recycling.
Cooking on open flames, they conjure up delicious dishes from all over the world in unusual places and without any electricity. This fiery adventure is fun, slows the pace down and brings the team together. Whatever the weather and whatever the season.
The ingredients are unusual too: The recipes often call for unusual ingredients, but they can also be simple treats from the farmer next door. Selected with care, the produce is cooked fresh in accordance with their own character – because flavour enhancers and convenience have no place here. The focus is on the essentials for once. As I said: less is more.

image.name: Calçotada in French-speaking Switzerland with chill food

data.name: Voyage Culinaire
data.abstract: Enjoy a culinary experience consisting of team spirit, fun and sightseeing!
data.description: This culinary event is composed of a guided tour through Bern and gastronomic team activities revolving around the topics of food and drink. Enjoy a 3-course menu in 1-2 different venues and a wine presentation of the wines you have selected for dinner.

data.name: Tasty food from Vreni’s garden
data.description: Vreni Hofer-Galli lives in in Dieterswil near Bern in a house which is more than 200 years old. Since both her daughters have moved out, the farming woman is delighted to host guests. Vegetables, salad, squash – all from her garden, just like the plums she uses for the dessert.

price.description: CHF 46.00 per child CHF 96.00 incl. wine

data.name: Eiger-Rotstock - via ferrata with a feel of the North Face
data.abstract: The via ferrata on the Rotstock, 260 metres in length, is a route for via ferrata walkers and experienced mountain walkers with a head for heights (and with the right safety equipment). The key to the climb is the vertical section immediately after the start. In the event of snow, strong rain or ice, this is very definitely not a route to be climbed. Like anywhere else on the Eiger, rock-falls cannot be ruled out.
data.description:
Difficulty
K2. Slightly to moderately difficult.
Valley/Starting-point:
Eigergletscher station (2,320 m), by rail from Interlaken Ost via Wengen or Grindelwald and Kleine Scheidegg (2,061 m).

Walk-in
From the Eigergletscher station, follow the Eiger Trail to the grassy hillock at Wart, and then follow paths up to the start point at 2,400 m, behind a mountain-top, with the Rotstockschlucht gorge immediately to your left: 45 minutes. 
Eiger-Rotstock via ferrata:
The course of the route via the new-old via ferrata is easily visible; easy walking sections are marked only with cairns. From the saddle of Rotstock, you quickly climb in stages onto the flat peak of Rotstock (2,663 m), with sheer faces on all sides; 1 hour 15 minutes from the start. 

Descent
Head back to the saddle and then to the south-west, across scree and slab sections (cairns and fixed ropes) down to the Eigergletscher station; 45 minutes. 


[/imglib/USP/k_buch.jpg] Quelle:
Eugen E. Hüsler/Daniel Anker: Wandern vertikal. Die Klettersteige der Schweiz, AT Verlag, Baden 2004  

Region: Bernese Oberland, North Wall of the Eiger 
Peak: Rotstock (2,663 m)
Time required: climb 2 hours, descent 45 minutes.
Variation in height: climb and descent 420 m.

For this trail, we recommend checking with the local tourism organization [https://grindelwald.swiss/en/service/operating-status/status-of-installations.html] in advance to confirm if it is open.

data.name: Garden of the Hotel DuPeyrou
data.abstract: Time seems to have stood still in the impressive 18th-century Palais with its smartened-up French garden, despite its close proximity to the busy city centre. The Hotel DuPeyrou was once surrounded by vineyards, and the gardens that belonged to it stretched all the way to Lake Neuchâtel.
data.description:
The Hotel DuPeyrou, one of the city’s most beautiful buildings, lies amidst a well-maintained French garden. The wonderful manor house in a Louis XVI style was built over the period from 1765 to 1770 for Pierre-Alexandre DuPeyrou by a Bernese architect who had been trained in Paris. Together with its annexes, the hotel forms a typically baroque estate, ringed by gardens with a symmetrical design.

In the 18th century, the estate’s gardens stretched all the way down to Lake Neuchâtel, which at that time flowed around the area of Seevorstadt. The building beyond the street that has undergone significant renovations is the former greenhouse, from which the shore of Lake Neuchâtel could once be reached. This is where DuPeyrou had the first of the lake promenade’s trees planted.

data.name: Climbing Weissmies
data.description: The hikers are taking the gondola up to Hohsaas before the ascent of the Weissmies begins. A mountain guide leads the way through the craggy terrain up to the 4023 m summit. From there they can see the Bernese Oberland and the Bernina mountain chain, beyond the Monte Rosa range. Physical fitness is required.

data.name: A farm in the Lakes region
data.description: Farm woman Vreni Hofer-Galli from Dieterswil in the Bernese Lakes region loves to grow vegetables and flowers in her garden. Her two daughters have moved out of the 200-year old farm, leaving Vreni with much time and space to pamper her guests with delicious home-grown products in an attractive environment.

price.description: CHF 46.00 per child CHF 96.00 incl. wine

data.name: Wispile
data.abstract: The mountain ridge to the south of Gstaad is well known to hikers as the most beautiful starting point for the panoramic hike to the hugely popular Lauenensee lake. A gondola takes visitors up to Höhi Wispile.
data.description:
Switzerland’s first “Funi” rope lift began operating here in 1935. Two large sledges, bound together by rope and driven by an electric motor, carried up to one hundred people per hour 300 metres up the mountain in winter. Today, the gondola ride to the top of Gstaad’s local mountain is much more comfortable.

The Wispile is a mountain for the whole family. There is a petting zoo with Falabella horses, pygmy goats and pigs, a tree adventure park, while the Märli-Onkel storytelling uncle and Bärg z’Morge mountain breakfasts are every bit as popular as the cheese trail (including Alpine cheese dairy tour) or peaceful Silentiumplatz with its hammocks, firepit and wood for grilling.

The highest mountain in the Arosa region accessible by cable car offers impressive views as far as Chur and to the south across the Graubünden Alps to Piz Bernina.

Altitude: 1,907 metres 
How to get there: 
Train to Zweisimmen, change for Gstaad; or MOB from Montreux to Gstaad, walk through the centre of Gstaad to the two-stage Wispile gondola 
Views: Gstaad and Saanenland, Lauenental valley, Diablerets massif 
Attractions: Petting zoo, cheese trail, scooter rides from Bodme, good thermal drafts make this a great starting point for paragliding 
Food and drink: Local specialities 
Accommodation: 6 double rooms and dormitories 
Groups: Several rooms with seating for up to 120 people, sun terrace with seating for 230 
Winter: One of the Gstaad winter sports areas, toboggan run to Gsteig 
Special comments: Arnold Annen from Lauenen invented funicular snow sledge ropeway technology in the 1930s
Discounted mountain ascent with the Swiss Travel Pass/GA travelcard.
Buy your tickets on arrival at the station.



DAY TRIPS TO THE MOUNTAINS
Buy your return rail and mountain ascent tickets now

Timetable and tickets [https://www.sbb.ch/de/kaufen/pages/fahrplan/fahrplan.xhtml?&nach=HöhiWispile]

data.name: Wine Tour Via Valtellina
data.abstract: For centuries Graubünden and Vorarlberg have imported wine from Valtellina One of the mule traders’ routes runs from Valtellina via Davos to Montafon.
data.description:
The historic route has experienced a renaissance as Via Valtellina, an attractive long distance hiking trail. World famous vacation destinations such as Schruns, Klosters, Davos or Pontresina vie for attention with lonely side valleys like the Schlappin-Valley or the Val Funtauna. In Tirano, vineyards and palaces with views of the imposing Bernina mountain world beckon to you. 
Length

130 km
7 stages
Elevation (uphill):
Gargellen (A)-Tirano (I): 5600m
Tirano (I)-Gargellen (A): 6600m

Requirements:
Technique: average
Condition: difficult, top fitness required

data.name: Quad Tour
data.abstract: Guided Quadtours in winter and summer up in the Swiss Alps.
data.description: Are you ready for an adventure? Our guided quad tours with local guide leads to the beautiful nature of the Bernese Oberland! Enjoy the fun of quad biking and discover the local farms in the unique mountains of Switzerland. Learn how the farmers and their families make cheese and enjoy a homemade brunch or aperitif. Our tours are unique and suitable for everyone. Dont miss it!

data.name: Hammetschwand lift and Felsenweg path
data.abstract: The 152.8 meter-high lift to the Bürgenstock looks like a heaven-bound rocket. And views from Hammetschwand over Lucerne and its lake are best described as heavenly!
data.description:
Warning! Before you make the trip, check if the Felsenweg and the Hammetschwand Lift are open. Find more information here [https://www.felsenweg.ch/].

The Felsenweg path begins in the middle of the Bürgenstock Resort, between the chapel and Parisa – Persian Cuisine. Along the path, twelve panels tell the impressive story of the Bürgenstock Resort. Over 150 years ago, two visionary friends, Bucher and Durrer, discovered the Bürgenberg and soon opened the first hotel. Their boundless pioneering spirit led to extraordinary technical achievements: the first funicular railway in Switzerland, the highest and fastest open-air lift in Europe, a revolutionary hydroelectric power plant, and the Felsenweg path itself. A story full of success, innovation, and incredible visions – don't miss this truly breathtaking story. All information is available via mobile phone.

The lift along the rock face has been the fastest way to the "highest viewpoint in the city of Lucerne" since the beginning of the last century: from the valley station inside the rock, it takes just under a minute to reach fresh air again. In the summer, the lift tower is illuminated at night and is easily visible from Lucerne. From Hammetschwand (already in the canton of Nidwalden), hiking trails lead back to the Bürgenstock Resort on Lake Lucerne, or you can return via the "Känzeli" along the Felsenweg path.

Altitude: 1128m 
Accessibility: 
In summer, there are 3 boat connections from Lucerne to Kehrsiten-Bürgenstock; connection with the Bürgenstock bahn from the lake to the Bürgenstock Resort on Lake Lucerne; from Stansstad, take the postbus to Bürgenstock (groups must reserve their journey with the postbus in advance); the Felsenweg path leads to the valley station of the Hammetschwand lift (only in summer).
View: Over the Lake Lucerne "Kreuztrichter", Rigi, Mythen, Buochserhorn, Stanserhorn, Pilatus and Brünig Pass and Bernese Alps in the background 
Attractions: The scenic Felsenweg path offers in-depth views over the lake across to the extraordinary lift 
Culinary aspects: Taverne 1879, Verbena Restaurant and Bärgbeizli Hammetschwand 
Overnight stays: 3 hotels in the Bürgenstock Resort on Lake Lucerne (ranging from 3* to 5* Superior) 
Winter: The Felsenweg path, Hammetschwand lift and Bärgbeizli Hammetschwand are not open in winter

data.name: Lauchernalp
data.abstract: Above the treeline, on a terrace created by a glacier, you soon discover the sun-spoilt Alps of the Lötschen Valley: Kummenalp, Hockenalp, Lauchernalp, Weritzalp and Tellialp.
data.description:
From the attractive Wiler village in the Lötschen Valley, a cable car takes the bite out of the 570-meter climb in altitude to the Lauchernalp – where a small and pleasing holiday resort with mountain guesthouses and chalets has slowly developed.

Scenic highland path with clear views of the Bietschhorn on either side – and ten tree trunks along the path to the Fafleralp presenting some interesting old Lötschental sayings. Pass hikes lead to the Lötschen Pass in the Gasterntal (Kandersteg) valley and over the Resti Pass to Leukerbad. INFORMATION

Altitude: 1969m 
Accessibility: 
Lötschberg train from Bern/Thun or from Brig to Goppenstein, PostBus to Wiler, cable car to the Lauchernalp; PostBus back from the Fafleralp 
View: Over the Lötschen Valley up to the Lötschenlücke and across to the mighty Bietschhorn, side views of the Weisshorn and Dent Blanche 
Attractions: Lötschental valley sayings and highland path via the Schwarzsee lake to Lauchernalp, Monster-scooter rides down to the valley. 
Culinary aspects: Mountain restaurants and mountain huts with local produce and tasty specialities 
Overnight stays: Alpenhotel zur Wildi, Berghaus Lauchernalp, Hotel Fafleralp, Gasthaus Kummenalp and hut on the Lötschen Pass 
Groups: Zudili panorama restaurant 150 people as well as for seminars, Restaurant Bärgsunna 40 people, Berghaus Lauchernalp 
Winter: Winter sports region; on the Hockenhorngrat, Europe’s highest winter hiking path at over 3,000 meter altitude 
Special comments: Glacier rail to the 3086 meter-high Hockenhorn runs solely in winter

data.name: Pierre Avoi – viewing ridge
data.abstract: A piece of rock reigning proudly over the Rhone Valley. Its name could stem from "pierre à voir"– seen from everywhere, or perhaps denote the rock to see!
data.description:
Alone views from the Pierre Avoi over the Grand Combin to Trient region (with Mont Blanc barely visible from the Pierre Avoi summit) and Dents du Midi, to the depths of the Rhone Valley and opposite-lying Vaud and Bernese Alps make journeying here worthwhile. 

Ascent to the Pierre Avoi from Savoleyres, from Croix de Coeur or from the west from Col des Planches or Col du Lein. The final 50 meters to the top lead over a staircase and ladders secured by chains – with the recommended descent from the south leading over Chute du Bisse to Verbier.INFORMATION

Altitude: 2473m 
Accessibility: 
Train to Le Châble, Postbus to Verbier, local bus to the valley station, gondola railway to Savoleyres; or train to Riddes and bus to La Tzoumaz: or from Riddes via the Isérables cable car and local bus to La Tzoumaz, gondola railway to Savoleyres 
View: Over the Grand Combin, Trient region and Rhone Valley as far as the Bernese Alps 
Attractions: Savoleyres: Trip from the Rhone Valley to Verbier by gondola rail with magnificent views on either side; climbing the Pierre Avoi 
Culinary aspects: Savoleyres: Italian specialities and homemade Pizza 
Overnight stays: no possible accommodation in Savoleyres 
Groups: 180 indoor seating places, 60 terrace seating places 
Winter: Winter sports region Verbier – La Tzoumaz 
Special comments: Only during the summer months: Possible private car journeys as far as Croix de Coeur

data.name: Tobogganing on Muottas Muragl
data.abstract: 20 curves and rapid straights take you through pine and larch forests down this 4.2 km long toboggan run. An amazingly varied and exciting run is guaranteed for both young and old alike.
data.description:
It is an easy ride by funicular railway to the starting point for this toboggan run. First admire the panoramic views of the Upper Engadin with the Engadin lakes and the Bernina mountain range and enjoy refreshments at the mountain hotel before making your rapid descent to Punt Muragl. 
Starting point: Muottas Muragl (2,456 m.a.s.l.)
Accessibility of starting point: Funicular railway 
Finishing point: Punt Muragl (1,738 m.a.s.l.)
Altitude difference: 718 metres
Length: 4.2 kilometres
Level of difficulty: Medium
Toboggan hire onsite: Yes
Illuminated for night sledging: No
Option to eat: At the start

data.name: Musical radio play "Jimmy Flitz - e Reis dür d Schwyz"
data.abstract: This delightful story is told in 6 episodes by dialect-speaking actors such as Büne Huber, Corin Curschellas, Steff la Cheffe, Marco Rima, Hanery Ammann, Christine Lauterburg.
data.description:
"Jimmy Flitz, e Reis dür d Schwyz" is not only breathtakingly funny, it is also deeply humane and takes you to some of the loveliest spots in Switzerland. 

On their way to the mysterious Menhiren, past thundering waterfalls and sacred lakes, a mouse and tiger-fly meet a bear-wolf, a vulture and a dragon. On foot and on wing, by train, boat and hot-air balloon, they traverse the highest passes and the deepest gorges... Immerse yourself in this mysterious world populated by fabulous mythical creatures! The story is a tribute by Bernese musician Roland Zoss to his favourite hero of them all, the cheeky little mouse Jimmy Flitz. This is dialect drama at its very best!

Suitable for children aged 5 and over and for all miraculous wonderbirds and wandering wolves!

The multi-part dialect musical radio play is available over-the-counter. 

Sample: Jimmy Flitz' adventures [http://www.mx3.ch/artist/jimmyflitz]MORE INFORMATION

Jimmy-Flitz iPhone App: Jimmy Flitz [http://itunes.apple.com/app/jimmy-flitz/id519502116?mt=8] 
Xenegugeli ABC App for playful learning of the ABC. Available for iPad and iPhone: Xenegugeli ABC [https://itunes.apple.com/ch/app/abc-dino-english/id669449038?mt=8]

data.name: Skiing in the light of the full moon
data.abstract: A mountain, a cable car, a mountain restaurant and free use of a slope in the mystical moonlight: this is the fabulous experience of skiing in the light of the full moon on the Diavolezza.
data.description: Glüna Plaina is the Romansh word for the full moon. Friday is always a special day for keen skiers and snowboarders in the Engadin as they head to Diavolezza. When the full moon starts to glow, the mountain railway beckons night skiers. The slopes are freshly prepared and lit only by the moonlight. The joyous mood is infectious. A dream opportunity for anyone fascinated by the moon or those who didn’t get their fill of the slopes during the day. The cable cars run from 7:30 p.m. to 11 p.m. To replenish your strength, why not meet at the summit to dine in the mountain restaurant. Some people take a moment on the terrace before or after the meal to simply enjoy the panoramic views: the Piz Palü, the Bernina range, the glacier – in the moonlight, it all looks simply “fabulus”, which means “fairytale” in Romansch.

data.name: Winter hike from Kandersteg-Sunnbüel to the Gemmi Pass
data.abstract: Retracing a route of historical significance: the old mule track from Sunnbüel above Kandersteg to the Gemmi Pass leads through a lonely, impressive and unique winter landscape.
data.description:
During the Middle Ages, the Gemmi Pass was one of the most important links for goods and people travelling between the Bernese Oberland and Valais. These days, the mule track across the Alpine plateau is an exciting hiking trail – even in winter. The cable car from Kandersteg to Sunnbüel covers the first 700 metres of ascent in just 10 minutes. Here, at the tree line, at 1,200 metres above sea level, the four-hour winter hike begins. It passes through the broad basin of the Spittelmatte and, in a short ascent taking about 30 minutes, climbs to the Schwarenbach mountain hotel. 

Originally built as a customs post in 1742, this establishment has hosted celebrated figures such as Mark Twain, Lenin and Pablo Picasso. Even the exterior of the Schwarenbach is impressive, bringing history to life. After some light refreshments, continue up the sunny side of the valley until a wide area opens up – the frozen, snow-covered Daubensee lake at 2,200 metres above sea level. If you have enough power in your legs you can complete the last 100 metres of the ascent on foot. Alternatively, the 8-person gondola will whisk exhausted hikers up to the Gemmi Pass, the final destination for this route and a spectacular lookout point.

With a bit of luck, you might even spot a bearded vulture flying overhead at the pass. These raptors have re-established themselves here in recent years, and the opportunities to observe them are unrivalled anywhere in Europe.

data.name: Gemsstock
data.abstract: Climb up 1,500m in altitude from Andermatt to the Gemsstock, at almost 3,000m above sea level. From this vantage point that is truly in the heart of the Swiss Alps, you have all-round views sweeping across half of Switzerland.
data.description:
Gemsstock – paradise for freeriders and downhill pros

Perfect deep snow, challenging steep slopes and descents of 1,500m in altitude: the Andermatt-Gemsstock ski region has much to delight powder pros. At almost 3,000m above sea level, the Gemsstock is the ideal spot for off-piste fun in the Gotthard region. From November to May, freeriders can make perfect tracks down slopes in a blanket of deep powder. Experts can demonstrate their skill on the descent from the glacier and follow in the tracks of an Olympic champion on the Bernhard Russi Run. Andermatt-Gemsstock – freeriders and expert skiers will love it here.


Altitude: 2,961m 
Getting there: train from Göschenen (Gotthard Line), Disentis or Brig to Andermatt, free Andermatt-Hospental ski bus in winter, two consecutive cable cars to Gemsstock via Gurschenalp middle station 
Views: more than 600 peaks from the Gemsstock: from Pizzo Centrale and the Gotthard region, Rheinwaldhorn, Monte Rosa and the Bernese Alps, all the way to Urserental valley, Galenstock, Sustenhorn, Schöllenen Gorge, Windgällen, Tödi and Graubünden 
Attractions: Bernhard Russi Run, downhills of up to 1,500m in altitude
Food/drink: Gummel, Pastakeller, Rondodrom, Gadäbar
Accommodation: Andermatt (no accommodation options at Gemsstock or Gurschenalp)

data.name: Chocolate tour
data.description: This city walking tour traces the history of the chocolate makers of Bern’s old town centre. Shepherded by an experienced guide, guests will follow the footsteps of the city’s famous chocolate pioneers. Stopping off at the premises of Tobler, Bloch, Suchard & Wander they will hear some of the stories behind Bern’s chocolate industry and get to sample some of the classic products for themselves. Next comes a chocolate tasting session at Casa Nobile, a modern chocolatier. Here guests will be introduced to the secrets of the world’s cacao-producing regions. The tour is rounded off with a visit to the former factory of Rodolphe Lindt, who invented melt-in-the-mouth chocolate in the Matte District in 1879.

data.name: Train through the Albula
data.description: The guests in the engine of a locomotive are travelling high up – either through the Albula valley or on the Bernina line, the highest railway route in the Alps. The retired train driver explains details of the machines along the way. A diploma and snapshots are available at the end.

data.name: Pouillerel Circuit
data.abstract: This trail takes you from La Chaux-de-Fonds to the Ferme Modéle and runs along the Pouillerel mountain crest most of the way.
data.description:
On a clear day the highest points along the trail offer views of the southern Alps, from Mont Blanc across to the Bernese Alps. If you look to the north you will see the landscape stretching all the way to the Vosges Mountains beyond the French Jura. The trai lstarts at the La Sombaille car park.

Details:
Length of the course: 15 km
Difference in altitude: 180 m
Time required: approximately 2 hours.

data.name: Tea culture in the Länggasse
data.abstract: Main shop, boutique of curiosities, small tea restaurant, professional advice, seminars and introductory courses to the Japanese tea ceremony: this internationally renowned shop has everything the tea-loving heart might desire.
data.description:
Katrin and Gerhard Lange opened their Länggass-Tee tea shop on 25 October 1983. Its fame now extends far beyond the city of Bern. Alongside selling good and affordable everyday teas, classic top-quality rarities from China, Taiwan, Japan and Korea, tea sets and other accessories, it also offers training to individuals and catering establishments.

More information [https://www.laenggasstee.ch/index.php?menuid=&getlang=en]

data.name: Sunnegga - Rothorn
data.abstract: Some people say that the Matterhorn is best viewed from the Rothorn, since it showcases its pyramid shape perfectly. And who are we to argue? The mountains to the east of Zermatt are great viewpoints.
data.description:
The journey into the mountains begins with the underground funicular railway to Sunnegga (2,288 metres above sea level). This was the first funicular in Switzerland to travel entirely inside a tunnel. At Sunnegga you can watch marmots at play, while the nearby Leisee lake is the perfect spot for a swim.

 The journey then continues by eight-person gondola to Blauherd (2,571 metres above sea level). From here, the themed Marmot Trail leads back to Sunnegga and the five-lake trail into the valley of the Findel Glacier.

Finally, a big cable car takes visitors to the summit of the Unterrothorn (3,103 metres above sea level). The views of most of the 38 four-thousand-metre peaks around Zermatt are quite simply breathtaking.



Altitude: 3,103 metres 
How to get there: Train from Brig/Visp to Zermatt, on foot or by free e-bus (green line) to the valley station Sunnegga-Rothorn: funicular to Sunnegga [https://www.matterhornparadise.ch/en/experience/peaks/sunnegga], gondola to Blauherd [https://www.matterhornparadise.ch/en/experience/peaks/blauherd], cable car to the Rothorn [https://www.matterhornparadise.ch/en/experience/peaks/rothorn]
Views: Across Zermatt to the Obergabelhorn, Zinalrothorn and Weisshorn, with the Bernese Alps in the background, over the Findel Glacier to the Rimpfischhorn and Strahlhorn, over the Gornergrat ridge to Monte Rosa and of course the Matterhorn itself 
Attractions: Starting point to numerous themed hiking trails (e.g. Five Lakes Walk, Path to Freedom, Flower Trail), Moonlight descent in winter, Sunrise rides, Leisee lake with children’s playground
Food and drink: Mountain restaurants at all levels, sun terraces with magnificent mountain views, Rothorn cablecar: Sunrise rides including Älpler breakfast every Tuesday during summer
Accommodation: No accommodation at Sunnegga, Blauherd or Rothorn; Fluhalp has single, double, triple, quadruple and group rooms, Mountain Lodge Ze Seewjinu has double, triple, quadruple and group rooms
Groups: Rothorn has two rooms with seating for 76 in each; Blauherd Blue Lounge; Sunegga has rooms with seating for 192, 140 and 100, conferences for up to 200, meeting rooms 
Winter: Rothorn Paradise winter sports area, linked to the Gornergrat and Matterhorn Paradise 
Special comments: Probably the most photogenic angle for Matterhorn views!

Book your tickets [https://www.matterhornparadise.ch/en/book/tickets/rothorn]

data.name: Switzerland's Stadium Wankdorf
data.description: The STADE DE SUISSE is more than just the home stadium of the long-established Bernese football club, the Young Boys. Far more! It is a meeting point, shopping centre, business centre, temple for gourmets...!

data.name: City Hall
data.description: As a symbol of municipal authority, the Hôtel de Ville (city hall) enjoys a strategic location opposite the picturesque Place de la Palud. This is undoubtedly Lausanne’s most beautiful 17th century Baroque building. Its main façade with its detailed arrangement shows Bernese influences. Worthy of special attention are the bell tower, the sculptured portal, the wonderful gargoyles, the half hipped roof and picturesque decorations. In bygone days the arcades that open onto the square were the scene of public debate – now however they are home to exhibitions of all types. A romantic archway leads to the Place de la Louve.

data.name: Red polenta of Valle di Muggio
data.description: Mara Bernasconi and Samuele Somaini live in the small hamlet of Casima in the Valle di Muggio near Mendrisio where they cook genuine Ticino specialties with local products for their guests. The polenta is ground from red corn in an old stone mill on the river.

price.description: CHF 76.00 excl. wine CHF 96.00 incl. wine CHF 46.00 per child

data.name: Historical Points
data.abstract: The city that began as a monastery. Lucerne traces its roots directly to St.Leodegar monastery, a small 8th century Benedictine cloister. Over the centuries a community grew along the Reuss River from the monastery to a nearby settlement. Historians regard Lucerne’s birth date to be 1178, when the parish was officially transferred from the monastery to the city. Middle Age fortifications, such as the famous Chapel Bridge, are timeless witnesses of the city’s rapid growth.
data.description:
HIGHLIGHTS IN LUZERN.
Religious sites [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/interests/excursions/religious-sites.html?start=26]
Overnight at a monestary [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/accommodation/other_types/extraordinary-hotels-in-switzerland/overnights-in-a-monastery.html]
Christmas Markets [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/event_calendar/event_results.cfm?f2=stxmas] 
NICHOLAS VON FLÜE
St. Nicholas of Flüe lived in the 15th century at a quiet river gorge near Lucerne. Commonly called “Brother Klaus,” he began his life as a successful farmer, town councilor and husband. But at 50 Nicholas felt God’s pull toward a life of seclusion. With the support of his wife and 10 children, Brother Klaus became a hermit and lived out his remaining years as a spiritual counselor and skillful arbitrator of political disputes. He was instrumental in arbitrating several treaties and political disputes, earning a reputation as a peacemaker and the role of Switzerland’s patron saint, being respected by Catholics and Protestants alike. Several sites related to his life are active pilgrimage sites, including his home and retreat in Ranft George near Flüeli-Ranft and his grave in Sachseln. 

ABBEY OF EINSIEDELN
In 828 Meinrad, a Ben edictine monk from Lake Constance, withdrew as a hermit to a secluded mountain valley east of Lucerne. There, Meinrad lived and prayed in solitude until 861, when he was killed by bandits. St.Meinrad’s retreat forms the core of the monastery at Einsiedeln, located only 1 hour east of Lucerne. Set on the location of St.Meinrad’s retreat, Einsiedeln (which means “hermitage”) has attracted the devout for over 1,000 years. Eberhart became the first abbot of the community under Benedictine rule in the 10th century. Pilgrimage to the monastery began no later than the 14th century, when the monastery acquired the Black Madonna, an icon so named for the black candle smoke that colors her skin and the infant Jesus. The Black Madonna is usually clothed in elaborate attire and resides in the Lady Chapel, which rests over the site of St.Meinrad’s cell. The chapel in turn resides within the nave of the baroque Abbey Church. Huldrych Zwingli, leader of the Swiss Reformation, served briefly as a priest at Einsiedeln but moved to Zürich where he persuaded thousands to join the Protestant Reformation.

JESUIT CHURCH
The Jesuit Church is the first large sacral Baroque building in Switzerland and was constructed in 1666 by Father Christoph Vogler for the Jesuits. The vault was redecorated in the mid-18th century. The original vestments of Brother Klaus, are stored in the inner chapel.
THE INTERNATIONAL MUSEUM OF THE REFORMATION
This museum is a must-see for religious visitors that come to Geneva, Switzerland. It begins with an emphasis on the Bible and includes some of the oldest French and English Bibles. Unique objects, manuscripts, rare books, engravings and paintings illustrate the close ties of Geneva and John Calvin to the Reformation.
more info [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/interests/excursions/religious-sites/musee-international-de-la-reforme-international-museum-of-the-reformation-genf.html]
OVERNIGHT IN A MONASTERY
Experience how it is to live in a monastery and overnight in one of the various abbeys and monasteries in Switzerland that offer simple accommodation. Some even offer their own mountain hut refuge to rent, like the convent of St.John in Muestair
more info [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/accommodation/other_types/extraordinary-hotels-in-switzerland/overnights-in-a-monastery.html?all]
THE PILGRIMAGE WAY OF ST. JAMES ALONG SWITZERLAND’S BREATHTAKING MOUNTAIN SCENERY.
Walk or cycle on St. James' footsteps, following his ways through the breathtaking mountain scenery of Switzerland to Santiago de Compostela. Take your time to visit some of the traditional pilgrims' stations.
more info [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/home/summervacations/excursion-summer/summer-mountain-tips/the-way-itself-is-the-goal.html]
CHRISTMAS MARKETS.
The Christmas season will soon be here again.. as well as the traditional Christmas markets in Switzerland. Montreux is home to the largest one, Bremgarten (Aargau) to one of the biggest ones in terms of vendors. The highest one can be visited on Mt. Pilatus. Others can be found in Huttwil (Bern), Zürich or Basel. 
more info [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/service-updates/events.html?strubrik=2161]

data.name: In the footsteps of Annemarie Schwarzenbach
data.abstract: This three-day tour of the Upper Engadin follows in the footsteps of the Swiss traveller, writer and photographer.
data.description: The hike is dedicated to Annemarie Schwarzenbach, one of the most colourful figures in Swiss cultural history. The photos and texts by the photographer and writer document the violent upheavals of her time, but also personal issues, such as dislocation and homosexuality. After extensive exploration of the Middle East, Central Asia, the USA, and Central and North Africa, Annemarie Schwarzenbach returned to her home in Sils Baselgia, where she rented a house on Lake Sils for herself and her friends. The three-day hike in the Upper Engadin takes the group past majestic mountain lakes at the base of the Albula range, the Bernina range and the Morteratsch glacier.

data.name: A culinary stroll
data.description: Herb expert Maria-Luisa Wenger lives on her farm Le cerneux Veusil in the Freiberge region in the Bernese Jura. She knows the wild plants, shrubs and trees in the area. Maria-Luisa takes her guests along on a stroll to collect herbs and taste edible plants. The guests experience nature with all their senses.

data.name: Jacuzzi Diavolezza at 3,000 metres above sea level
data.abstract: Relax in alternating hot and cold baths at almost 3,000 metres above sea level – what could be more relaxing after an eventful day in the fabulous mountains?
data.description:
The hot tub sits grandly on the sun terrace of Berghaus Diavolezza, bubbling away at a pleasant 41 degrees. The view of Piz Bernina and Piz Palü and the glaciers is breathtaking, whether in sunshine or at night under the starry sky.

Advance booking required. Includes a towel, bathrobe, iced water and fruit.

Getting there: By cable car to the Diavolezza. By train or car to Diavolezza valley station (parking available).

data.name: La Balade de la Sorcière – Witches’ Trail
data.abstract: The medieval town of La Neuveville on Lake Biel has something for the whole family to enjoy, from an easy three-hour walk packed with tales of witches to the lake shore and colourful old town.
data.description:
The four-kilometre Witches’ Trail starts and ends at the railway station in La Neuveville. The first information board shows the route of the circular hike. We recommend taking the path up to the vineyards of La Neuveville, so that the legendary
waterfall with its “Witches’ Bathtub” then follows as the crowning highlight.

After the steep ascent through the vineyards, you will be rewarded with fantastic views of the town, Lake Biel and St. Peter’s Island. The trail leads from one information panel to the next, following picturesque paths through idyllic natural surroundings. If you need to, recharge your batteries in the forest picnic area and take in some wonderful views. On the Witches’ Trail, hikers not only find out more about the secrets of La Neuvevillle but also learn about the hidden powers of medicinal plants, trees, stones and water.

Hidden behind dense trees is the legendary waterfall, at the bottom of which the local witches are said to have bathed. Even today, you can cool off in the knee-deep clear water of the stone basin. The path continues down past vineyards, stately houses with enchanting gardens and along the shores of Lake Biel back into the town.

Additional information is available from Jura bernois Tourisme in La Neuveville, where for three francs you can buy an information brochure on the Witches’ Trail in French and German.



More information [https://www.j3l.ch/de/V1596/hexenpfad]

data.name: Therme Zurzach
data.abstract: Wellness in Switzerland’s largest thermal baths. The varied experiences on offer at Therme Zurzach invite visitors to take a moment and relax.
data.description:
The history of Bad Zurzach [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/bad-zurzach/]as a spa resort began in 1914, when hot spring water was discovered by chance while drilling for salt. This has been bubbling up to the surface from a depth of around 400 metres since 1955.

Today, Therme Zurzach [https://www.thermezurzach.ch/]is one of the largest thermal spa resorts in Switzerland. The soothing warmth and precious minerals from the rocks of the Zurzach sodium sulphate spring have a relaxing and vitalising effect.

This varied spa landscape is the perfect place to leave your day-to-day life behind you. In the outdoor area, you can enjoy the wonderfully warm thermal water in four pools even in the depths of winter. Head to the unheated natural swimming pool in the spa’s gardens to cool off. In the evening, underwater lights create a special ambience in the wellness pool. Choose between four pools in the indoor area of the spa for a diverse experience. These include the intensive brine bath that promises deep relaxation thanks to the high salt content, cave-like ambience and underwater music.

Therapeutic bathing can be supplemented with the stimulating effect of heat from the “textile” saunas, in which bathing suits can be worn, and the crystal steam bath. The relaxing and rejuvenating experiences are rounded off by indoor and outdoor zones for relaxation and lounging, surrounded by beautiful parkland, a restaurant and two bars.

In the exclusive, textile-free bore rig sauna landscape – which is based on the history of salt drilling in Bad Zurzach – several saunas, steam baths and a cold water pool as well as an elegant bar and lounge area provide an unforgettable boost to wellbeing.

Younger guests will enjoy the indoor Papa Moll children’s paddling pool and the water playground outside.

Arrival
Bad Zurzach train station is just a few minutes’ walk from the thermal baths (50 minutes from Zurich, 1 hour 30 minutes from Bern). The thermal bath also has its own bus stop served by local buses: “Bad Zurzach, Therme”. To the timetable [https://www.sbb.ch/de]
Paid parking is also available for those making the journey by car.

data.name: ISTA The Avalanche Training For You
data.abstract: Do you enjoy nature, mountains and skiing? Do you want more freedom, pleasure and safety? Do you care for yourself and for your friends?
data.description:
A NEW APPROACH

Despite the increasing number of backcountry recreationists, training opportunities, both in Switzerland and abroad, vary from country to country and mainly cater to advanced amateurs and professionals. ISTA’s training program is intended for the general public and is delivered by affiliated instructors and guides. The goal is not to provide extra equipment, but rather the knowledge and skills required to assess and prevent risk.
Inspired by the model of the Professional Association of Diving Instructors (PADI), ISTA offers a progressive international certification. Over 40 experts spanning 9 countries and 3 continents in the areas of education, sport psychology, transfer of knowledge, nutrition, meteorology, snow science, risk management and rescue methods, as well as mountain guides and ski instructors, were involved in the development of this unprecedented project in this fast-growing and increasingly exposed sector. Two modules are currently being covered - Discovery and ST1. The courses are supported by illustrated books featuring simple, clear, precise and playful descriptions, available in 4 languages (EN, FR, DE, IT).WHY?

Avalanches are not a fatality. Practitioners change, habits change – risks don’t. ISTA is the new essential approach to managing them.

ISTA is an international program that uses a standard universal language.

ISTA allows you to progress through various levels with a standardized method that is adapted to every skill level.

ISTA aims to foster knowledge sharing, exchange and the development of an international community.

All ISTA-certified participants benefit from the ISTA rewards program and its exclusive offers on travel, equipment and tourism services.DISCOVERY

[http://img.myswitzerland.com/669890]
The DISCOVERY course is a one-day introduction to the ISTA program. It is intended to introduce participants to the fundamentals of backcountry risk prevention and provide them with an overview of the range of skills to be developed. The main goal of the course is to inspire participants to continue learning.

After the course, participants will be able to:
 * follow the risk assessment process with the help of the course book
 * follow the crisis management process with the help of the avalanche rescue procedure

ST1

[http://img.myswitzerland.com/669891]
The ST1 course teaches basic avalanche risk prevention skills over two days. The goal of the course is for participants to acquire the basic skills and knowledge required to carry out the risk management process, implement rescue procedures and use rescue equipment.

After the course, with the help of the course book, participants will be able to:
 * Implement the risk assessment process
 * Identify favourable and unfavourable terrain
 * Understand rescue techniques
 * Use rescue gear
 * Implement the avalanche rescue procedure
 * Use the HFSA© system to assess mental, medical and energy-related risk factors

WHERE?

[http://img.myswitzerland.com/670065]
ISTA courses can be found in 28 Swiss resorts. Search for an instructor in your area here:

www.ista-education.com/en/where-find-us [http://www.ista-education.com/en/where-find-us]

data.name: Hotel Rigi Kulm
data.abstract: The Hotel Rigi Kulm has been welcoming guests for almost 200 years.
data.description:
Remarkable for its unique location on the summit of the queen of the peaks, this hotel has 70 beds for hikers, individualists, walkers and nature-lovers. It is also the perfect place for a short break. Having been extensively renovated, the hotel is to reopen at the end of April 2007.INFORMATION

Sunset:
For nearly 200 years all guests have been enchanted by the sunset and sunrise rising over Mt. Rigi. Guests, who don’t stay overnight on the Rigi, can ride the cogwheel train up to Vitznau during the summer months.

By public transport:
From Lucerne to Goldau or Küssnacht and then by local bus to Weggis or Vitznau
From Zürich Airport / Main Station to Lucerne and then by boat to Weggis / Vitznau, or from Zürich Airport / Main Station to Goldau.

By car:
From Berne: take the A1 / A2 motorway, from Basel the A2, from Zürich the A4, all of them in the direction of the Gotthard. Exit: Küssnacht (for Vitznau / Weggis) or Goldau (for Goldau) 

By boat:
 * From Lucerne Bahnhofplatz to Weggis or Vitznau
 * By train to Arth and then by local bus to Goldau


Mt. Rigi is serviced by two railways and a cable car and hence is easy to reach:
 * cog railway Vitznau - Rigi Kulm
 * cog railway Goldau - Rigi Kulm
 * cable car Weggis - Rigi Kaltbad

data.name: Viewpoint: Tavel memorial
data.description: Views of the Alps from the Längenberg, near Gschneit/Oberbütschel. Popular year-round place for walking, in winter there's even a little hill so the children can have fun sledging. The well-known writer from Bern, Rudolf von Tavel (1866–1934) was the first person to write the history of Bern and other articles in local dialect: "Ds Bärnerland isch i dr Morgestilli gläge mit aller syr währschafte, brave Schönheit..." (The Bernese landscape lies in the quiet of the morning with all its unspoilt, wonderful beauty…)

data.name: Historical Points
data.abstract: Home of the Swiss Reformation The story of Christianity in Zürich begins in the 4th century with the tale of the city’s patron saints, Felix and Regula. Threatened with execution due to their faith, the Roman siblings fled to Zürich, where they were captured and beheaded. It is said they picked up their heads after death and walked to the riverbank before collapsing. Their relics are now preserved in the Fraumünster, famous for its stained glass windows created by Marc Chagall.
data.description:
HIGHLIGHTS IN ZÜRICH
Religious sites [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/interests/excursions/religious-sites.html?start=26]
Overnight at a monestary [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/accommodation/other_types/extraordinary-hotels-in-switzerland/overnights-in-a-monastery.html]
Christmas Markets [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/event_calendar/event_results.cfm?f2=stxmas] 
BIRTH OF THE SWISS REFORMATION
Zürich made its most significant mark on Christian history in the early 16th century with Huldrych Zwingli and the Swiss Reformation. Zwingli spent his career working for church reforms, having grown disillusioned with the corruption and distortion prevalent in Rome. He publicly denounced the Catholic church’s reliance on saints as spiritual mediators. So engaged were the Zürchers of the early 16th century that they quickly embraced Zwingli’s Protestant doctrine, and in 1523 Zürich’s city council elected to become a Protestant city.

THE ANABAPTISTS
Among Zwingli’s closest followers were Conrad Grebel and Felix Manz. The Anabaptists, as they were called, pressed for separation of church and state, adult baptism, freedom from taxation and military conscription. Zwingli couldn’t agree to such radical measures, nor could the Zürich city council. After refusing either to conform or to leave Zürich, the Anabaptists experienced their first martyrdom in 1527 when Felix Manz was executed by drowning. But while Manz was dead, he had begun a movement that would last, spreading throughout Switzerland, Germany and the Netherlands, and giving root to the modern-day Mennonite and Amish communities in North America. Several Lake Zürich towns were founded by Anabaptist communities in exile, where they resided or worshiped in secrecy caves. A visit to the Anabaptist cave in Bäretswil is a powerful reminder of the lengths early believers took to worship as they saw fit.

LAKESIDE METROPOLIS 
A lakeside metropolis with views of the snow-covered Alps, Zürich offers a mix of unique activities waiting to be discovered. A shopping paradise with renowned international as well as unique local brands. Delicious culinary treats, over 50 museums and more than 100 galleries, a world clas((s Opera House and numerous events invite visitors to spend time here and to explore the well- preserved Old Town, which can look back on a 2,000-year history. 

THE INTERNATIONAL MUSEUM OF THE REFORMATION
This museum is a must-see for religious visitors that come to Geneva, Switzerland. It begins with an emphasis on the Bible and includes some of the oldest French and English Bibles. Unique objects, manuscripts, rare books, engravings and paintings illustrate the close ties of Geneva and John Calvin to the Reformation.
more info [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/interests/excursions/religious-sites/musee-international-de-la-reforme-international-museum-of-the-reformation-genf.html]
OVERNIGHT IN A MONASTERY
Experience how it is to live in a monastery and overnight in one of the various abbeys and monasteries in Switzerland that offer simple accommodation. Some even offer their own mountain hut refuge to rent, like the convent of St.John in Muestair
more info [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/accommodation/other_types/extraordinary-hotels-in-switzerland/overnights-in-a-monastery.html?all]
THE PILGRIMAGE WAY OF ST. JAMES ALONG SWITZERLAND’S BREATHTAKING MOUNTAIN SCENERY.
Walk or cycle on St. James' footsteps, following his ways through the breathtaking mountain scenery of Switzerland to Santiago de Compostela. Take your time to visit some of the traditional pilgrims' stations.
more info [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/home/summervacations/excursion-summer/summer-mountain-tips/the-way-itself-is-the-goal.html]
CHRISTMAS MARKETS.
The Christmas season will soon be here again.. as well as the traditional Christmas markets in Switzerland. Montreux is home to the largest one, Bremgarten (Aargau) to one of the biggest ones in terms of vendors. The highest one can be visited on Mt. Pilatus. Others can be found in Huttwil (Bern), Zürich or Basel. 
more info [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/service-updates/events.html?strubrik=2161]

data.name: Two-day Bollywood tour
data.description: Since 1964 over 200 Indian movies have been shot in Switzerland. The blockbusters from Bollywood brought more and more guests from India to Switzerland. The guests visit some of the original locations of Bollywood films in Zurich, Lucerne and the Bernese Oberland with the guides of Erwin Tours.

data.name: Augustinian Monte Carasso Monastery
data.abstract: The foundation of the monastery and its associated church dates back to the year 1450. However, the mid-19th century saw the monastery closed and left to decay. It was only in the eighties of the 20th century that the monastery was shaken awake through a total renovation – and brought back to life at the village center under the supervision of the eminent Swiss architect Luigi Snozzi.
data.description:
Instead of the original idea of decentralization, Snozzi’s project viewed added value to the historic village core. The former monastery therefore developed into a modern community center for diverse public and religious institutions - and a pioneering example of planning in public space. In 1993 the project was thus awarded the Wakker Prize, along with further recognition through the «1993 Prince of Wales» award. Today, individual rooms of the monastery can be rented for seminars. 

Also worth a visit: the church of San Bernardo, higher above, with remarkable frescoes from the 15th to 17th centuries. The key to the church is obtainable from valley station of the cable car station to Mornera.

data.name: Bonstetten Park
data.abstract: Bonstetten Park serves throughout the year as a valuable public recreational area right on the lakeside: BBQ sites, open grassy areas and a playground make the park a popular destination for families as well.
data.description: A small wooded area, several avenues and the nearby nature reserve of Gwattlischenmoos are a perfect setting for long walks. The Bonstettengut in Thun/Gwatt is a former manor of the Lords of Strättligen. In a document from 1273 a Rudolf von Strättligen is named as the owner. Emanuel Fischer had the essential core of today's parkland established, with its extensive gardens, between 1763 and 1811. The Bellerive country estate dates from 1764 and has belonged to the canton of Bern and city of Thun since 1960. Today, the Bellerive houses the Musikschule Region Thun.

data.name: Hiking opportunities on the Young Rhine / Senda Sursilvana
data.abstract: When the Rhine flows past Chur, it has already passed some of the most beautiful landscapes on its entire route to the North Sea. Hiking along the banks of the Young Rhine is a real treat indeed.
data.description:
Discover the beauty of nature along the Young Rhine while hiking. The Senda Sursilvana, from the Oberalp Pass to Chur, is the perfect way to do this and you can experience 100 km of this route in four stages.

The "Walking week on the Young Rhine" is yet another hiking offer. With Chur as your base, you go on 4 guided walks in 7 days and enjoy some extraordinary scenery. On your rest days you have the opportunity to experience the history of the Alpine City and to enjoy a ride on the Bernina Express.

data.name: Monte Generoso
data.abstract: At the southern end of Lake Lugano is the 1,704 metre high Monte Generoso. This lofty altitude makes it without a doubt the best mountain for views in the canton of Ticino.
data.description:
The new restaurant “Fiore di pietra” (stone flower) created by the famous architect Mario Botta stands majestically on a rugged plateau on the mountain. Its windows offer breathtaking 360° panoramic views, taking in the lakes, the city of Lugano as well as the Matterhorn and Jungfrau all the way to the Bernina Range.

Nostalgic journey to the summit
A cog railway has been taking visitors up to the peak of Monte Generoso for 125 to enjoy these breathtaking views. It is about 9km long and runs along a magical stretch of mountain scenery in the Monte Generoso nature park. In addition to electric trains, nostalgic modes of transport also use this cog railway line, including the oldest steam train still in operation in Switzerland, built in 1890, and trains from the 1950s. A ride in these trains brings the time of the Belle Époque back to life.

Activities on and around the mountain
There is much to discover on Monte Generoso: Keen hikers can explore the mountain on more than 51km of hiking trails. The Nature Trail and the Ice Pits Nevere are just two of the many hiking paths. The Ice Pits Nevere trail takes hikers to restored ice huts, which were once used to chill milk before it was churned into butter. The brave can marvel at the landscape around Monte Generoso from the air by paragliding from the top. Flights start on Monte Generoso and glide in different directions over the lakes, countryside and towns.

INFORMATION
How to get there:
Drive or take public transportation from Lugano to Capolago-Riva San Vitale, from there take the Monte Generoso mountain train to the top of Monte Generoso.

Sunset:
If you get a chance, don’t miss the sunset in Ticino. It’s a truly spectacular experience.

Food/drink:
The “Fiore di pietra” gourmet restaurant and “Generoso” self-service restaurant will satisfy your hunger and thirst after a leisurely stroll or strenuous hike.

Families:
The “Bear Cave” is about 30 minutes from the “Fiore di pietra” building on the Italian side of the mountain. Some 60,000 years ago, it was home to more than 800 cave bears. The cave's length is 200m, 70m of which have been made accessible to visitors. You need sturdy shoes, hiking gear and a hat to follow in the footsteps of the cave bears.

Please note:
Reduced rate mountain rail ascent with the Swiss Travel Pass / GA travelcard.
Buy your tickets on arrival at the station.

More information about Monte Generoso [https://www.montegeneroso.ch/en]


MOUNTAIN DAY TRIPS
Buy your mountain rail ascent return tickets now

Timetable and tickets [https://www.sbb.ch/en/buying/pages/fahrplan/fahrplan.xhtml?&nach=GenerosoVetta]

additionalDescriptions.description: The Ferrovia Monte Generoso stands out for its exclusive locations, ideal for tasting culinary excellence, celebrating memorable private events or holding impactful corporate meetings. At 1'704 meters above sea level stands the "Fiore di pietra", an architectural gem that has two restaurants inside: one à la carte for high-class gastronomic experiences and one self-service, perfect for convivial moments. In addition, there is also a unique panoramic conference room inside, capable of accommodating up to 80 people and perfectly adaptable to different needs. At the midway station, however, you cannot miss the iconic Bellavista Buffet. This charming grotto offers a cozy setting with about 40 places, also ideal for private events. Here regional, zero-mile cuisine reigns supreme, delighting guests with traditional Ticino dishes.

What better place to begin your life as a couple than on the cogwheel train and the summit of Monte Generoso? Between breathtaking views and boundless valleys, the "Fiore di pietra" offers a fairytale stage for your wedding. With its distinctive architecture and a 360-degree panoramic terrace, every moment is transformed into an unforgettable memory, embraced by nature and the sky. At this magical venue, every detail contributes to making your special day a daydream.

data.name: Baltschieder - Via ferrata;
data.abstract: Alpine, rather sparsely secured route with a hut at the end of the fixed-rope section. Fabulous scenery of the Baltschied Valley; the descent is a non-stop feast for the eyes.
data.description:
Difficulty
Fixed-rope route level 3-4. Due to its length this is a challenging via ferrata (mountain trail with fixed cable); most exciting passages at the beginning and by the distinctive tower, in between however also lots of grassy patches (flowers!), which is why hikers are recommended to attempt this route in dry weather conditions only. 
Hikers opting for the "Nostril Route" (Nasenlöcher-Route) need headlamps, a 20-metre rope and a few biners and links for intermediate securing. 

Starting point
Ausserberg (1008 m) at the Lötschberg South Ramp. Bus from Visp.

Ascent to fixed-rope route
From Ausserberg (1008 m) initially on tarmac along the sunny hillside up to the Niwärch, an old irrigation channel. Then along a narrow trail ascending gently with the irrigation channel to the picturesque Baltschied Valley. Behind the huts of the Üsser Senntum (1287m above sea level) the mighty trench which runs straight down from the Wiwanni Hut soon comes into view; the via ferrata runs across the ridge to the right of it. Blue markings indicate the way from the valley trail (plain) across stony meadows and rocks to the mouth of the Klamm and, to the right of it, the beginning of the fixed-rope route marked with a large red exclamation mark (about 1780m above sea level).

Baltschied fixed-rope route
Immediately along the wire rope up a steep incline over rock steps and gullies onto the huge, partly grass-covered slope and continuing to ascend sharply up to a distinctive rock tower. From there around the tower on the right and along a very exposed route section diagonally down to a notch; then over rocks and a ridge rib back onto a grassy patch and along the wire rope to the end of the fixed-rope route (about 2440m). Follow the track heading over to the left to reach the Wiwanni Hut (2463m) which has been visible for some time. 

Descent
Along the hut trail marked white-red-white down to the Lerchwald, then keeping left to the avalanche barriers. From here in a zigzag line down to a country track. The country track soon turns into a small road which in big loops descends down to the Telwald. The road crosses over the Niwärch at a few huts and eventually leads to Ausserberg. 


[http://img.myswitzerland.com/gad/12879/images/k_buch.jpg] Quelle:
Eugen E. Hüsler/Daniel Anker: Wandern vertikal. Die Klettersteige der Schweiz, AT Verlag, Baden 2004 

Region: Southern Bernese Alps, Bietschhorn Group
Summit/culmination point: Wiwanni Hut (2463m above sea level)
Hiking times: Ascent to fixed-rope route 2 h 45 min., fixed-rope route 2 h 45 min., descent 2 h 30 min.; 8 hours in total.
Difference in altitude: 1500m

data.name: Idyllic winter outing to the Moléson
data.abstract: The Moléson mountain in the canton of Fribourg has much to offer, from snow shoe tours and ski tours to freeride adventures – come snowfall or blazing sunshine. There are many signposted trails on which to explore this charming untouched landscape.
data.description: The Moléson, a unique mountain of the Swiss Prealps, is just half an hour from Fribourg. This famous mountain has much to offer. After a snow shoe or ski tour, savour the glorious views from the mountain restaurant. Or take the leisurely way to the top by mountain railway and enjoy a fondue moitié-moitié, with breathtaking views far into the distance to the north and west, plus of the impressive mountain ranges in the Valais and Bernese Alps to the south and east. Local mountain guide Sébastien Fragnière will put together the perfect experience for any taste and fancy.

data.name: Rapid drive over the pass and slow-down in the spa
data.abstract: Enjoy the timeless Alpine landscape around Andermatt at the steering wheel of a Morgan Plus 4. Follow this up in the luxurious atmosphere of five-star hotel The Chedi.
data.description:
Racing up and down the pass in a Morgan Plus 4 is a unique adventure that should be on everybody’s to-do list next summer! How about the breathtaking San Bernardino? The Tremola or Furka and Nufenen passes? They are all just waiting to be discovered by car fans. Follow this with some wonderful relaxation in The Chedi – either in the spa or in its outstanding restaurant.
Includes
 * 1 night in a deluxe room or deluxe suite
 * 1 x day trip in a Morgan Plus4
 * 1 x 3-course dinner at The Restaurant (excl. drinks) per stay.
 * Welcome drink on arrival
 * The Chedi Grand breakfast buffet
 * Admission to The Spa " Health Club
 * Alcohol-free drinks from the minibar
 * In-room entertainment
 * Wi-Fi Internet access in the room/suite and in the hotel’s public areas
 * Daily newspaper

General Terms " Conditions of Business
 * This offer is valid for a stay of 1 night
 * Each additional night can be booked according to availability and the “best available rates”
 * All services that are not enjoyed during the stay cannot be redeemed for cash or exchanged for other services
 * Prices are based on availability at the time of booking

data.name: The Kambly Experience
data.abstract: The Kambly Experience at Trubschachen is an exciting venue for the senses, where visitors can discover the secrets behind the art of baking quality biscuits, explore the origins of Kambly and savour moments of sweet delight.
data.description:
The Kambly Experience
Immerse yourself in the world of Kambly in the idyllic Emmen Valley and discover the secrets of fine biscuit baking. Explore the origins of this traditional brand in the original Kambly bakery and learn more about Switzerland’s most popular biscuit brand in an interactive way at the experience stations. As you follow production through the factory, you will gain an insight into the individual production steps – from making the dough to dispatch around the world. A wide variety of Kambly specialties and gifts await in the factory shop. 
More information [https://kambly.com/en/kambly-experience/]

Confectionery demonstration
Each day, visitors can watch demonstrations by a master confectioner and discover the secrets behind the art of baking quality biscuits. Children and adults can also book to bake their own biscuit creations.
More information [https://kambly.com/en/kambly-experience/events-with-kambly/]

Kambly Café
Enjoy a refreshing drink, a delicious cup of coffee or an exquisite tea in the Kambly Café, accompanied by a small treat from the Kambly confectioners of course. We will be happy to serve you a handmade dessert from our master confectioners too.

Factory shop
Around 100 different types of biscuit are available to buy in the factory shop. In addition to the popular 500g factory shop bags, you will find some great gifts and sweet souvenirs for friends and family. 

Kambly train
Daily hourly connections with BLS from Bern and Lucerne to Trubschachen. The Kambly train [https://kambly.com/en/kambly-experience/the-kambly-train/] brings guests directly to the Kambly Experience from Tuesday to Sunday. 

The Kambly Experience Tour
On the 30 km e-bike Kambly Experience Tour from Langnau, visitors will learn more about the origins of the raw materials for the fine Kambly specialties, as well as experiencing the diversity of Emmen Valley. Those who follow the fully signposted route no. 777 through the characteristically hilly Emmental landscape can enjoy breathtaking views over mountain and valley. Duration: travel time 2.5 hours
More information [https://kambly.com/en/kambly-experience/experience-out-about/kambly-experience-tour/]Other destinations near the Kambly Experience 
There are many other exciting places to discover not far from the Kambly Experience. We have compiled a number of outing ideas, restaurants, accommodation options and bookable offers for groups and individual guests.
More information [https://kambly.com/en/kambly-experience/experience-out-about/suggestions-for-excursions/]



INFORMATION
Opening hours:
Mon-Fri 9 a.m. - 6 p.m.
Sat, Sun 9 a.m. - 5 p.m.
Special opening hours on public holidays [https://kambly.com/en/openinghours/]

The Kambly Experience is accessible for wheelchair users and admission is free.

data.name: Gondola to Lake Oeschinen
data.abstract: One of the most beautiful and perhaps most impressive mountain lakes can be reached by gondola from Kandersteg. The gondola also carries walkers looking to hike over the Hohtürli pass into the Kiental valley.
data.description:
For 60 years, people sat sideways in the open two-seater chair lift, enjoying direct views of the Doldenhorn as they were carried up towards Lake Oeschinen. Today, guests are whisked up the mountain in modern, colourful eight-seater gondola cabins. From the upper station you can enjoy wonderful views of the Lake Oeschinen valley basin and across the valley from Kandersteg to the Wildstrubel and Lohner.

It is a 25-minute stroll to the lake, or you can take an electric taxi. Lake Oeschinen marks the western gateway to the Jungfrau Aletsch Unesco World Heritage site.

A thrilling summer toboggan run is located right next to the upper station – quite the change of pace after the tranquillity of the mountain lake. Further information [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/lake-oeschinen/]INFORMATION

Altitude: 1,682 metres 
How to get there: 
Lötschberger train from Bern/Thun/Spiez directly to Kandersteg, then gondola to the Oeschinen upper station 
Views: From the upper station: Lake Oeschinen valley basin with the Blüemlisalphorn, Fründenhorn and Dolderhorn; across the valley from Kandersteg to the Wildstrubel and Lohner 
Attractions: Summer toboggan run next to the upper gondola station, rowing on Lake Oeschinen. 
Food and drink: Restaurant Bergstübli (upper station), Restaurant Oeschinensee (lamb stew, fruit cakes), Berghaus Oeschinensee mountain inn (grilled cheese sandwiches, barbecue area) 
Accommodation: Hotel Oeschinensee: 30 beds in rustic rooms, 20 sleeping spaces in dormitories
Mountain inn: Single, double and multi-bed rooms 
Groups: By arrangement in the mountain inns 
Winter: Small winter sports area, winter hikes to the lake, ice fishing 
Special comments: Lake Oeschinen is the western gateway to the Jungfrau Aletsch Unesco World Heritage site.

data.name: Säntis cable car
data.abstract: The journey in the big Säntis cable car from Schwägalp across the rocky ridges to the mountain station is an impressive experience in itself. And once you reach the “weather mountain”, the view of six different countries will take your breath away.
data.description:
The railway line to Wasserauen constructed at the beginning of the last century was actually the first section of a planned railway up the Säntis. The railway line never got further than the valley town, however, and so the cable car from Schwägalp to the top of the Säntis was opened in 1935. From the valley station, you glide almost weightlessly up to the imposing summit in around 10 minutes. At 2,502 metres above sea level, on clear days the mountain provides breathtaking views of France, Germany, Italy, Austria, Liechtenstein and Switzerland. 

The Säntis also plays a key role in weather forecasting – a weather station was first installed on the mountain way back in 1882. An experiential world brings the impressive natural phenomena and their elementary effects to life. A second experiential world – “Säntis – the Ice World” – was opened in 2020. Visitors learn all about snow, ice, ice crystals and glaciers through a series of fun activities and displays.

In summer, numerous special experiences such as full moon trips, sunrise ascents or Säntis-Spitzegnoss evenings attract visitors to the mountain.INFORMATION
Altitude: 2,502 m.a.s.l.
How to get there: Train to Urnäsch or Nesslau, PostBus to Schwägalp, cable car to the Säntis in 10 minutes
Views: Across the Appenzell region and the Alpstein mountain range to Lake Constance, Vorarlberg, the Graubünden Alps as far as the Bernina, in particular the Churfirsten range and beyond them the Tödi, Finsteraarhorn, Pilatus and Rigi, and across the Swiss Plateau to the Jura and Black Forest 
Attractions: Identify mountains and valleys from the viewing terraces, enjoy splendid sunrises and sunsets, full moon trips, a night on the Säntis 
Food and drink: Large, modern Säntisgipfel restaurant
Alter Säntis mountain inn (summer only) 
Accommodation: Alter Säntis mountain inn: Double and multi-bed rooms, dormitories (summer only) 
Hotel Schwägalp: Double rooms and tourist dormitories 
Groups: Rooms for events at the summit and at Schwägalp (extensive event brochure available online)
Alter Säntis has space for 90 guests (function room) 
Operating times: Säntis cable car runs all year round (brief closure for maintenance, usually in January/February, check the timetable [https://saentisbahn.ch/en/experience/cablecar/timetable/])
Swiss Travel Pass/GA travelcard: Discounted mountain ascent with Swiss Travel Pass/GA travelcard. Buy your tickets at the station
Special comments: Charter trips can be arranged outside of the normal timetable with advance notice



DAY TRIPS TO THE MOUNTAINS
Buy your return rail and mountain ascent tickets now

Timetable and tickets [https://www.sbb.ch/de/kaufen/pages/fahrplan/fahrplan.xhtml?nach=Säntis]

data.name: Stählibuck Tower
data.abstract: High up on the «Stählibuck» mountain of Frauenfeld a steel giant of the same name is keeping watch: the Stählibuck Tower. With a height of 27 meters, it is a challenge for anybody who attempts to climb its 148 stairs.
data.description: The reward for the trouble is a fantastic panoramic view, starting in the east with the Voralberg and all the way to the Bernese Alps in the west. And if you are hungry after the long climb, there will be lovely grilling places at the bottom of the tower. The Stählibuck Tower is one of the oldest lattice towers in Switzerland. The over 100-year-old Stählibuck Tower is one of the oldest steel lattice towers in Switzerland and was even used as a watch tower for airplanes during World War II.

data.name: Payerneland
data.abstract: Payerneland has: - the largest indoors go-kart piste in Europe (900 m) - a 920 meter-long “Grand-Prix” racing track beneath open skies - the LauraPark: an amusement park for children from 2 to 20 years - Payerneland Adventure: an adventure park for sportive activities in healthy fresh air with all the family
data.description:
Here’s your chance to try the largest indoor kart track in Europe (900 m) as well as the 920-meter-long outdoors "Grand Prix" racing track - and delight in entertaining activities such as bouncy castle, trampoline, carousel and flitting around with mini-cars in the children's amusement park. And for children as of 4 years, "Payerneland Aventure", an adventure park for the whole family, offers six agility courses of varying levels of difficulty high in the trees. 

How to get there:
By car: from Lausanne or Bern, take the A1 motorway in the direction of Yverdon, exit at Payerne and follow the main road for 10 minutes.
By train: alight at the Swiss Railway stop Payerne.

data.name: Swiss Food and Culture Tour
data.description: Following a culinary introduction to Swiss food and culture with a cheese tasting in the centre of Interlaken, you will visit a chocolate shop and a local woodcarver, who specialises in traditional handicrafts from the Bernese Oberland. Finally, you will discover a local farm, where the farmer will guide you around key areas of the yard.

data.name: Kandersteg-Allmenalp via ferrata
data.abstract: The Kandersteg, a 350-metre high wall, is a direct route which is not really suitable for anxious beginners. However, there are regular platforms where you can stop off and calm that beating heart.
data.description:
A via ferrata in stunning countryside, along a 350-metre high wall, arranged in a series of columns and gorges, over which - and through which - the Allmibach flows, creating four waterfalls. For 20 years, paragliders have found promising thermals above this wall, which gets the full benefit of the morning sun. Since summer 2005, via ferrata climbers too have been making the climb, at a point not far from the northern end of the Lötschbergtunnel, to reach a cleverly laid-out via ferrata with a number of surprises in store. It is a route which does not artificially seek out the vertical, but does not shy away from it either. The Köppel brothers (who helped to design the Leukerbad via ferrata, the longest and most demanding in Switzerland) worked on the Kandersteg-Allmenalp via ferrata. As a result, the northern and southern ends of the Gemmi Pass, with its various climbs dating from the 18th century which can still evoke fear today, have modern iron ways for mountain sports enthusiasts who deliberately seek out the sensation of vertigo, and with safety in mind. 


Difficulty
K4; the key to the climb is the vertical wall shortly after the start, with the most spectacular passage being the route below and above the roof overhang. Two three-rope bridges, each around 30 metres in length, cross the Allmibach; instead of using the upper bridge, there is also the option of using a Tyrolienne traverse to skim over the water. Two more Tyrolienne traverses are planned, leading from the via ferrata off to the right, to the rocky head and then back down to the climb. These should guarantee even more of that adrenalin buzz. The Kandersteg-Allmenalp via ferrata is open from the start of June to mid-October, when the Allmenalp cable-car is running. Warning: construction is during June 2005; official opening on July 30, 2005.

Starting-point
Kandersteg rail station (1,176 m) or Allmenalp-Luftseilbahn valley station (1,181 m) to the south-west of the village.

Walk-in
From Kandersteg rail station, take the hiking route into the valley. Where the Allmibach flows into the river Kander, turn right and to the north of the stream, reaching the start of the via ferrata at roughly 1,250 m. From the Allmenalp-Luftseilbahn valley station, cross farmland and a private bridge over the stream to join the route already mentioned.

Route
Climb, keeping to the left, along a 100-metre high wall, vertical in places. Cross a three-rope bridge over the Allmibach. A grassed slope leads to a step, with a roof which projects over it by 10 metres and which is conquered using a unique piece of design (a suspended walkway and a ladder which turns through 180 degrees). To the left of the second-lowest waterfall, the climb rises to an edge, behind which the Allmibach roars and falls. A second three-rope bridge crosses it again - brave via ferrata climbers naturally elect for the option further up, involving travel along a 40-metre long suspended rope. To finish, there is a final wall to the exit point, at around 1,600 m. It is a 20-minute walk up to the Undere Allme (1,723 m) with the mountain station of the Allmenalpbahn and the "Beiz-" (inn). 

Descent
By cable-car. Alternatively, on foot via Ryharts and Schneitböde in 1 _ hours. Alternatively, take a tandem paraglider flight!

[http://img.myswitzerland.com/gad/12879/images/k_buch.jpg] Quelle:
Eugen E. Hüsler/Daniel Anker: Wandern vertikal. Die Klettersteige der Schweiz, AT Verlag, Baden 2004 

Region: Bernese Alps, Lötschberg
Peak: First (2,548 m) - as an alternative
Time required: 3.0 to 3.5 hours (10-20 minutes to the start of the via ferrata, depending on the starting point).
Variation in height: 550 m climb (via ferrata 350 m).

data.name: Crossing the suspension bridge Carasc
data.abstract: The mountainside above the Magadino Plain is the perfect place to enjoy a scenic hike. In addition to the breathtaking views, the tour also takes in several impressive sights.
data.description: The hike passes through vineyards on the way to the village of Curzútt, which is known for its extensive historical restoration. This old settlement is living proof that people long ago generally preferred to live at higher altitudes rather than on the Magadino Plain. Another highlight of the tour is the romantic San Bernardo church with its prized frescoes. Experience a rush of adrenaline and marvel at the impressive views as you cross the 270m long suspension bridge, one of the longest in Switzerland.
