data.name: Solothurn’s Bucheggberg woodland hikes
data.abstract: The Bucheggberger (Buechibärger) round-hike is a theme path that forms part of Solothurn’s woodland hikes. At times public excursions are offered - and many of the hiking routes provide interesting information on notice boards along the way.
data.description:
Start and finish of the lengthy Bucheggberg hike is the parking lot next to the Schloss Buchegg castle in Kyburg-Buchegg

The hilly Bucheggberg landscape rises gently from the flat Mittelland plains - and the beauty of this cultural landscape with its gently rolling hills, field and forest mosaics, tidy farmhouse villages, hedgerows and woodpiles present an idyllic corner of the earth. 

In the woods beech stocks remind one of the likelihood that the name Bucheggberg – translatable as beech mountain - is derived from the many beech trees with their attractive silver-grey bark and rust-red buds on delicate branches. These magnificent trees help shape the surrounding landscape - with views over the Jura and Bernese Alps further crowning the region’s beauty. 

No structures spoil the sight of this natural paradise, despite the cultural landscape having been shaped by human hands. In primeval times there were no meadows, paths or footbridges here, instead solely oak, ash and elm trees together with pastures shaping the so-called Mülitäli (as viewed at the start of the theme hike). Nowadays natural landscapes free of all kinds of structures alongside streams are few and far between; yet here in this remote valley, only the peaceful murmuring of the Mülibach stream interrupts the sound of silence.

data.name: Thurnheer Coopery
data.abstract: Centuries-old craftsmanship can be seen in the coopery. The cooper Martin Thurnheer demonstrates how an oak wood barrel is made by hand and gives information about Swiss wooden crafts.
data.description:
Since 1854, warehouse barrels, barriques, fermentation stands, wooden bathtubs and other wooden containers have been produced at the coopery Thurnheer in Berneck. The small family business is operated by the fith generation now. Swiss vintners use the barrels and barriques to enrich their wine with a special wood aroma. 
The tour of the coopery lasts about 90 minutes and can be combined with a visit to a wine cellar in Berneck.

data.name: Jungfrau Park - The Fantastic Mysteries of our World
data.abstract: For the first time ever, the great mysteries of the world are available at one location to be experienced and sensed.
data.description:
Jungfrau Park is a place where visitors can gain insight into unsolved riddles through models and multimedia presentations. 
Once your curiosity has been aroused, you leave your everyday life behind and submerge yourself in questions surrounding the earth's unsolved mysteries. Jungfrau Park offers this variety and much more in a one-of-a-kind adventure park situated between two lakes in the heart of the Bernese Oberland at Interlaken, against the backdrop of snow-capped mountains.
Important information: 
Summer: The entire Jungfrau Park is open daily from May to October 
Winter: From November to April the children's paradise Mysty Land is open exclusively. 
More information about the opening hours: http://www.jungfraupark.ch [http://www.jungfraupark.ch/index.php?id=129&L=2]MYSTY LAND

In the Mysty Land in the JungfrauPark Interlaken, children's eyes are brought to sparkle. Large climbing tower, bouncy castles, and much more. Thanks to the large indoor area, the children enjoy on winter days, unlimited play pleasure. 

Opening hours:
4 November 2017 to 22 April 2018 
Wednesday - Friday, 1 pm - 6 pm 
Saturday & Sunday, 11am - 6pm 


More information:
www.jungfraupark.ch [http://www.jungfraupark.ch] 
Tel. 033 827 57 57

data.name: Furkapass
data.abstract: The Furkapass links Andermatt in the Canton of Uri with Gletsch in the Canton of Valais. It is part of the popular Three-Pass-Ride over the Furka, Grimsel and Susten Pass. In summer, a ride with the nostalgic Furka steam engine from Realp to Gletsch is an unforgettable experience.
data.description:
Coming from the Reuss Valley, one rides through the Schöllenen Gorge, formerly an unsurpassable bottleneck on the Gotthard route via Andermatt into the Urseren Valley and Hospen Valley, where the road over the St. Gotthard Pass begins. In the rear of the Urseren Valley near the village of Realp, the Furka Pass road’s ascent starts. Here one can observe in summer the huffing and puffing of the Furka Train’s steam engine. After a few kilometers one reaches the hamlet of Tiefenbach. After riding over a slope-terrace the train climbs in tight curves to the peak at 2431 meters above sea level. Here you will have a panoramic view of the Gotthard Massif and the Urseren Valley. 

On the Valaisian side, at Hotel Bélvèdere, about three kilometers below the ridge of the Furka Pass, one can get a good view of the Rhone Glacier. An excursion to the glacier grotto, an ice chamber that is built every year anew, is definitely worth your while. The Rhone Glacier has lost some of its spectacular size due to climate change. In 1850 the river of ice reached far down into the valley basin, today the glacier tongue ends at the height of Hotel Belvedere. 

Gletsch in Upper Goms (1759 meters) at the foot of the Furka Pass and the Grimsel Pass (Bernese Oberland) is defined mainly by the enormous "Grand Hotel Glacier du Rhône", where the early 19th century atmosphere of the Age of Alpine Passes is palpable, and the small station of the Furka Steam Train. A 30-minute hike on the nature trail familiarizes visitors with the variety of the pre-glacier area, which is rich in pioneer plants. 

Since the opening of the Furka Base Tunnel between Realp and Oberwald im Goms in 1982 there is a railroad link (with car transfer) between the cantons of Uri and Valais that operates in winter. Still more attractive is the ride over the pass, by mountain bike, motorbike, automobile, or with the yellow Alpine PostBus.

data.name: Switzerland’s DDLJ tour
data.description: The Bollywood film “Dilwale Dulhanya Le Jayenge”, or DDLJ for short, is THE Indian love story of all times. The movie has been playing daily at the Maratha Mandir cinema in Mumbai for over 20 years. A third of it was filmed in Switzerland. The visitors travel to the original locations in the Bernese Oberland.

data.name: The lush meadows of Oberbalm
data.description: Vegetables, fruit, beef, flour and cider: The food of Melanie Ramser from Oberbalm near Bern is grown on her own farm. The meals are served to the guests in the granary built in 1782 or in front of the oven house. The Horbmatt farm is located in the midst of pastures with cattle, horses and goats.

data.name: Specialties from the Jura
data.description: Isabelle Habegger has been cooking for a quarter century. She also cooks for her guests visiting the “Ferme de la Combe” farm in Roches near Delsberg. It is located on Münsterberg with views of Weissenstein mountain. The food is home-grown or from the Bernese Jura area.

price.description: CHF 76.00 excl. wine CHF 46.00 per child CHF 96.00 incl. wine

data.name: Ski touring on Piz Badus
data.abstract: Tips for ski tours to the source of the Rhine This four-hour ski tour on the Gotthard massif takes you up 2,928-metre Piz Badus before descending more than 1,300 metres via the Maighelshütte to Tschamut.
data.description:
The tour starts at the Oberalp Pass, which can only be accessed by train during the winter, followed by a brief descent to Alp Milez. The ascent to Tomasee lake begins here; along the way, you will cross the Rhine, just 300 metres from its source. Covered in snow and ice, it is no obstacle. The final section lies at the far end of the lake and leads right up to the peak – Piz Badus. The fantastic panorama stretches as far as the Jungfrau in the Bernese Oberland or the Dufourspitze, which stands 4,634 metres high and is Switzerland’s highest peak. Up here, almost 3,000 metres above sea level, it is clear that this route is worth the effort: as is so often the case, the best has evidently been saved for last in the form of the Maighelshütte and subsequent descent to Tschamut.

The holiday destination of Disentis-Sedrun offers a wide range of options for ski tour lovers. One of its highlights is the tour to Piz Badus described above. This four-hour intermediate-level route can be undertaken with guides from Alpventura or Muntognas or can be completed on your own – provided you have the requisite knowledge.

More information [https://maps.graubuenden.ch/de/tour/skitour/piz-badus-six-madun/11447104/]

data.name: BEO-Funpark
data.abstract: The BEO Funpark, with its indoor and outdoor play paradise, promises fun for the entire family – rain or shine.
data.description:
Young and old can let off steam indoors on an area of around 2700 square metres. In addition to bouncy castles, trampolines, climbing rocks and suspension bridges, there is also a ball pool and slides.

When the weather is nice, the family is lured outside, where they can have fun on an area of 1500 square metres. Here the family can compete in pit-pat mini golf or curling.

Games such as the rope slide, knight's castle, Wabbelberg or trampoline will make children's hearts beat faster in the BEO fun park, even when the weather is fine.

If your stomach is rumbling after playing, the BEO-Funpark offers a large selection of delicious food and drinks.
Picnics are permitted in the indoor area in accordance with the regulations, which can be found on the website.

The BEO-Funpark is around 20 minutes' drive from Bern, Fribourg and Murten. There are plenty of parking spaces on site. If you are travelling by public transport, take the train to Laupen. From this stop, it is then a 10-minute walk to the Funpark.

From the beginning of October to the end of February, the BEO Funpark is open to children every Saturday from 10.00 am to 10.00 pm with the BEO Night Party (light show and disco music from 7.00 pm).
This offer is unique in Switzerland and an unforgettable experience for the children!

data.name: The legendary Jungfrau
data.abstract: The participants will hear many legends and stories on the guided hiking week around the Jungfrau.
data.description: The “Jungfrau Story for Women” summer offer is a hiking tour in the Unesco World Heritage region. In addition to enjoying the sensational mountain panorama, the hikers will hear a wealth of stories, legends and tales along the way. For example, they will hear the story of how the Jungfrau got its name. The routes have been designed to incorporate tips for women, women’s literature and stories about women in the Bernese Oberland. Hotel accommodation and luggage transport are all organised.

address.name: Women Travel Sonja Müller Lang GmbH

data.name: Hochwacht Lookout Tower
data.description:
At an altitude of 780 metres above sea level, the Hohwacht is the highest point in the eastern Oberaargau. The top of the tower (20 m) offers a magnificent panorama of the Mittelland from the Jura to the Alps. The scenery that surrounds this commanding height is definitely worth more than just one journey of discovery.

The Hohwacht on the Ghürn was a key fire-signal station until 1798. By day or by night, fire signals from the lookout towers in past years could alert the entire canton within a matter of 3 to 4 hours. The system was last used in 1798 when the French army attacked Bern.

data.name: Würth Sculpture Park
data.abstract: The sculpture park at the Forum Würth Chur forms part of the impressive Würth art collection, which has over 16,000 exhibits. The park is home to notable sculptures by international artists as a complement to the special exhibitions hosted in the main company building.
data.description: Visitors may admire the art on display in this 1.200 m2 area of the Forum Würth Chur. The Würth Building is open and transparent and so is also the park. All the sculptures are shown at their very best optical impact. On display are the works «Fontaine pour Joseph Siffert» by Jean Tinguely, «Le Monde», «Der Drache» and «Nana Mosaïque Noire» by Niki de Saint Phalle, «Tongue» by Not Vital, «Transformer 400» and «Loftshape 370» by Carlo Borer and «Dolittle» and «Bauerndenkmal» by Bernhard Luginbühl.

data.name: Cheese grotto
data.abstract: A monument to cheese: more than 3,000 wheels, including historic rarities, have been gathered here at the Gstaad cheese grotto.
data.description: The display, covering several storeys of a structure that extends for 25 m underground, is impressive and evocatively lit. A tour tells the story of cheese, from grass to gourmet palates.Descending a steep flight of wooden steps to the former community water reservoir, visitors gain insight into Berne’s AOC-certified Hobelkäse cheese speciality and production methods.

data.name: Via Snow, Cliffs and Meadows to the Source of the Saane River
data.abstract: This walk through the mountains is unique, taking you through several different types of countryside.
data.description:
Begin by taking the aerial cable car from the Col du Pillon to Glacier 3000. Here you are greeted by the first surprise: the mountain station was designed by star architect Mario Botta and sports a restaurant with glorious views. Follow the safe trail through the snowfields (incidentally, this is an area designed for summer skiing) to the Quille du Diable, a rock shaped like a giant thumb that stands out from amongst the Valaisan Alps. 
The lucky souls who do not suffer from vertigo can peer 1,500 meters down onto the area of Derborence, where a rockslide created the landscape many thousands of years ago. Continue along the path as it leads you downwards through snowfields and scree to the Cabane Prarochet, an ideal place to have lunch or a snack. 
As you approach the glacier, the path continues over rocks that have been polished due to erosion (les lapis) to the Sanetsch Pass and eventually, to the source of the Saane River. Here, the water bubbles up in the middle of a lush mountain meadow. Follow the high plateau and the Santesch dam and you will reach the famous mountain restaurant run by Jean-Maurice Luyet.
Up to this point, the hike should take about five hours. Thanks to the small aerial cable car (installed by the power plant for its maintenance workers) the tired hiker can take an easy way down to Gsteig, near Gstaad. 

Cable cars leave Les Diablerets every 20 minutes, and the journey lasts 15 minutes.

How to get to Les Diablerets Station:
By car: take the A9 motorway in the direction of Great St. Bernard, exit at Aigle then take the Aigle - Les Diablerets - Col du Pillon road (20 km).
By train: take the Paris - Lausanne TGV then the Intercity service to Aigle, or the Lyria Paris - Lausanne - Aigle TGV. In Switzerland there are direct trains to Aigle (Simplon and Geneva - Brig lines). Then take the ASD (Aigle - Sépey - Diablerets) mountain train. The Lausanne - Aigle stage of the journey takes 30 minutes and the Aigle - Les Diablerets stage of the journey takes 50 minutes.

data.name: Lama treks
data.abstract: Animal experiences: a hike across the snowy hills that overlook Lake Brienz in the company of creatures that seem almost cuddly.
data.description:
"No drama, llama! Trekking with these empathetic animals is a wonderful experience, especially for children. Llamas are attentive, cautious and gentle – but still look pretty big up close. And what about the spitting? Oxi Flück, a llama farmer from the Lake Brienz area, knows the answers to these kinds of questions. Under his guidance, people and animals get to know one another, before participants help him to groom the llamas. Any initial fears are soon dispelled. Children and adults alike are sure to fall in love with the camelids. Once the animals are saddled and the baggage is secured in place, the party sets out at a comfortable trot through the snowy meadows and forests above Brienz. Guests can have their luggage carried by the llamas if they wish. View after view of Lake Brienz opens up as they go, while the Bernese Alps tower majestically in the background. The fresh winter air really gives you an appetite – not to mention all that stomping around! Time for an outdoor fondue feast, cooked over the fire. A romantic end to a wonderful llama trek. 

"

data.name: Sulwald
data.abstract: The nostalgic red cable car carries passengers from the sunny mountain village of Isenfluh above Lauterbrunnen up to the hamlet of Sulwald. The cabin has enough room for eight people or one cow.
data.description:
The small, almost nostalgic cable car has been operating since 1975 and is inextricably linked with the life of the local community. It carries passengers to a marvellous hiking area with unique views of the three mighty peaks of the Bernese Oberland, the Eiger, Mönch and Jungfrau.

From here you can see the Grindelwald valley, the Schynige Platte ridge, deep into the Lauterbrunnen valley and of course the three giants of the Bernese Oberland, the Eiger, Mönch and Jungfrau. Those wishing to explore the Alpine landscape can climb to the little Sulseeli lake and the SAC Lobhorn hut, then continue on to the top of the Sulegg (2,413 metres). Other highlights include a monster scooter track (toboggan run in winter) and a trail devoted to nature, folklore and physical exercise.INFORMATION

Altitude: 1,520 metres 
How to get there: 
Bernese Oberland Railway from Interlaken Ost to Lauterbrunnen, PostBus to Isenfluh, cable car to Sulwald 
Views: Lauterbrunnen valley, Eiger, Mönch and Jungfrau 
Attractions: Mountain hikes, monster scooter track and exercise trail 
Food and drink: Sulwald-Stübli: cheese and game specialities (seasonal) 
Accommodation: SAC Lobhorn Hut (sleeps 24) 
Groups: ---- 
Winter: Open all year round, winter toboggan run, snowshoe trails, no skiing 
Special comments: There has only been a road to Isenfluh since 1962/63; a 1.2-kilometre spiral tunnel was added in 1992

data.name: Piz Nair
data.abstract: A stately ibex, head bowed, sits atop its throne on the summit of Piz Nair, overlooking the Upper Engadin at its feet.
data.description:
The Chantarella-Corviglia funicular railway takes you from the centre of St. Moritz up to the top of the resort’s local mountain. The Signal cable car from St. Moritz Bad also takes you in the direction of Corviglia. Another cable car then takes summiteers even closer to heaven and the Piz Nair upper station at exactly 3,056 metres above sea level. Without breaking a sweat or exerting yourself, you can enjoy an unforgettable view of St. Moritz, the Upper Engadin lake region and the mountains.

The summit falls away steeply on all sides, but with a sturdy pair of boots you can tackle the descent via the picturesque Lej Suvretta or into Valetta Schlattain. Mountain bikers love the descent of Alp Suvretta back to St. Moritz, with an altitude difference of 1,200 metres.

The “Clean Energy Tour [http://www.clean-energy.ch/fileadmin/user_upload_cleanenergy/user_upload/pdf/Clean_Energy_Tour_Flyer.pdf]” between Piz Nair and St. Moritz provides an extensive presentation of the “Energy from Water, Sun, Wind and Biomass” project.

Altitude: 3,022 metres 
How to get there: Train from Chur to St. Moritz, funicular railways to Chantarella/Corviglia, cable car to Piz Nair 
Views: Towards Muottas Muragl, the Piz Palü and Bernina region, Corvatsch, the Bregaglia Alps, Italy’s Monte Disgrazia in the distance; to the west and north lie Piz Julier, Piz Ela and Piz Kesch 
Attractions: View from the second-highest mountain in the Upper Engadin accessible by cable car; long bike descents 
Food and drink: Panorama restaurant on Piz Nair, restaurants in Corviglia and Lej da la Pêsch 
Accommodation: None on the summit 
Groups: In the panorama restaurant by arrangement 
Winter: Winter sports area of St. Moritz / Upper Engadin 
Special comments: The 60-year-old bronze ibex, “Guardiaun Grischun” is the symbol of Piz Nair.

data.name: Church of Santa Maria delle Grazie
data.abstract: Built in the late 15th century, Santa Maria delle Grazie is one of the most precious churches in Ticino.
data.description:
The inside of the church is a symphony of space and color. A wide transverse wall divides the room, typical of Franciscan churches, spanned by an impressive fresco that combines Renaissance elegance with spontaneous, decorative grace. A “Crucifixion” is enthroned in the middle, surrounded by fifteen pictures depicting the life of Christ, painted by a talented but unfortunately unknown Lombard artist between 1495 and 1505.

Another splendor is the fresco in the chapel on the right, dedicated to the Dormitio Mariae, with a wooden figure in a gilded urn. Attributed to the circle of Gaudenzio Ferrari, it radiates a special grace. Two other frescoes are also particularly valuable, one depicting St. Bernard between Saints Roch and Sebastian, and the “Annunciation” in the triumphal arch of the choir, attributed to a painter from the circle of Ambrogio Borgognone.

The church also houses paintings from the 17th and 18th centuries, old tombstones and wrought-iron grilles from the 16th and 18th centuries. One of the most precious churches in Ticino, which should be viewed with peace and reverence, owned by the city of Bellinzona.

data.name: Längenberger farmer's trail
data.abstract: Outstanding walking enjoyment combined with interesting information on agriculture.
data.description: This relaxing circular walk through the Bernese cultural landscape leads past impressive farmhouses and various forms of agriculture over its one and a half hours. Over and above this, the information panels acquaint visitors informally with agriculture in general, the specific crops grown here and livestock husbandry.

data.name: Guided adventure in a freeride paradise
data.abstract: Endless variety and spectacular views: There is a huge range of ski-touring and freeride opportunities near Gstaad. Mountain guides and ski instructors teach and assist guests from the planning stage of their tours to the final descent.
data.description:
Nestled in the Bernese Alps, Gstaad is a paradise for ski touring. There is something for everyone – from simple mountain trips in the Pre-Alps to challenging ski mountaineering tours. 

Careful planning, as well as an understanding of avalanches, snow, weather conditions, first aid and emergency measures are essential for ski tourers and freeriders. Freeride camps teach the basis for risk-aware, unguided skiing and snow sports in the mountains away from the secure environment of a ski resort. The focus is on having fun in the powder snow – but guests learn plenty too. 

Highly qualified guides and ski instructors accompany guests on heliskiing trips on request. The outings on offer range from descents of wide, untouched slopes to combinations of heliskiing, downhill skiing and ski touring. An unforgettable experience in all cases.

data.name: Eggiwil Emmental House Trail
data.abstract: The idyllic, hilly landscape of the Emmental is a picture of lushness. This goodness finds expression both in the valley’s produce – such as the world-famous cheese – and its architecture, notably the big farmhouses with low-slung roofs, flower-adorned façades and colourful gardens.
data.description:
You find fine examples along the short Eggiwil House Trail, which leads along the banks of the River Emme and through the adjacent flower-filled meadows. The farms typically consist of a complex of buildings: main house, granary, barn and smaller “Stöckli” house, traditionally for grandparents. Back in Eggiwil, stop at one of the inns for a popular delicacy – the Bernese platter, a feast of local meats and sausages.

On the “Verkehrsverein Eggwil” website you can download a brochure about the “Eggiwil Emmental House Trail”.

data.name: Tender veal from Obbürgen
data.description: Helping city folks understand agriculture – Bernadette Odermatt-Felber likes this idea. She cooks home-grown vegetables from her garden and tender veal from the farm for her guests. She serves the meals in her cosy living room in Obbürgen on Bürgenstock mountain.

price.description: CHF 96.00 incl. wine CHF 46.00 per child CHF 76.00 excl. wine

data.name: Panorama bridge Sigriswil
data.description: At 180 m, the visitors enjoy the spectacular views far into the Bernese Alps. The suspension bridge is 340 m long. Bridge rangers in smart uniforms know much about nature and technology, where the birds are nesting, how the bridge was built, or where to eat. Children up to 16 can cross the bridge for free.

price.description: CHF 8.00 without guest card CHF 0.00 per child

data.name: Activities in Sattel-Hochstuckli
data.abstract: The family mountain with revolving gondola lift, "Stuckli-Run" summer toboggan run, tubing run, Skywalk pedestrian suspension bridge, bouncy castle and scooter trekking are the highlights here.
data.description:
On the ride to Mostelberg, the colorful 8-seater gondola turns twice on its own axis. Children like to stay at the mountain station, as Rondo's children's world offers almost everything a child's heart desires with its toboggan run, tubing run and numerous bouncy castles and trampolines.

The "Skywalk" foot suspension bridge is 374 m long and one of the longest pedestrian suspension bridges in Europe, crossing the Lauitobel at a height of 58 m. If you don't want to experience the bridge a second time on the way back, take a hike in the direction of Herrenboden, Hochstuckli or Rothenthurm.

Views: From Mostelberg: to the Rigi mountain range, Wildspitz, Lake Aegeri with Morgarten, the Rotenthurm area; from Hochstuckli also the Mythen, the Schwyz basin with Lakes Lauerz and Lucerne, Central Switzerland and the Bernese Alps.
Attractions: Revolving gondola, pedestrian suspension bridge, Rondo's children's world, Geissä Wäg theme and adventure trail, Mythen round trip and panoramic circular hiking trails, high-altitude hike to Haggenegg

data.name: Aare tubing and more
data.abstract: The water sports equipment can be freely selected and mixed within a group. You'll be spoilt for choice, with options including tubes, two-seat kayaks, luxury tubes, stand up paddle boards (SUP) and six-seat dinghies.
data.description: Collect your reserved equipment, a life jacket and a watertight bag from the Aare tubing base in Uttingen near the river and you're ready to hit the water. Enjoy an unforgettable 18-kilometre ride on the crystal water as you watch the snow-covered Alps pass by in the distance. In the meantime, your luggage will be carried to Bern and you can easily continue your journey straight from there. A barbecue buffet at the end of the trip is another convenient option.

data.name: Lace up your hiking boots for your Alpine rendezvous
data.abstract: This two-day overnight offer has you hiking in the middle of nature in the UNESCO Biosphere Entlebuch, past flowering Alpine meadows, through cool forests and across marshy moorland.
data.description:
The first day of the hike treats you to magnificent views of Beichlengfähl all the way to Hilfernthal. Not long into the hike, you can enjoy a hearty early morning snack provided by the Schöpfer family in Hof Eygrat. Once you are back on the route heading in the direction of Beichlengfähl, it’s worth making a short detour along the high mountain trail to Beichlenkreuz. The view is fantastic. From here, you can see the surrounding mountains including the Bernese Alps and Jura mountain range. 

You will be staying overnight with the Wicki family in the Stotzig-Dorbach B"B, who will spoil you with a delicious dinner. There you will get a taste of the simple life of a mountain farmer, one without any luxury, which nature more than makes up for with a fantastic diversity of flora and a romantic sunset. On the second day, you set off after your alpine breakfast via the Hilfernpass through a moorland to Flühli. It’s worth stopping off for some natural kneipping in Schwandalpweiher – this will swiftly revive your aching feet.

data.name: Vernex Park
data.abstract: The Vernex Park is set on the shores of Lake Geneva next to the Auditorium Stravinsky and offers walkers a green area along the extension of the flourishing quays of the Montreux Riviera. Each July, one of the stages for the Montreux Jazz Festival is set up in this park.
data.description: Between its large, century-old trees and its majestic magnolias, the Vernex Park is home to several works of art, including the fountain "in memory of Vibeke" by Jean Flemming Soerensen and the Montrailes sculpture by Antoine Poncet. At one end of the park, busts of Richard Strauss and Miles Davis by Bernard Bavaud face each other, reminding visitors of the Montreux Riviera’s magnificent past. On the other side, the playground and slightly sloping lawn ensure that the Vernex Park remains a popular meeting place for families and for walkers seeking tranquility.

data.name: Chocolate dreams can come true
data.abstract: Create exquisite chocolates with the finest truffle and praline fillings or even make your own chocolate bars and figures from yummy Swiss chocolate. miniSchoggi makes all this – and much more – possible.
data.description:
miniSchoggi offers numerous options for a variety of different occasions. Team events, family parties or maybe even a sweet-tasting hen do – just let us know! We work with you to conjure up the perfect event and make the chocolate dreams of young and old come true. Let yourself be inspired because we know – we have something for everyone!

CHOCOLATES & TRUFFLES
Under the guidance of our professional confectioners, you learn the art of filling chocolates, sealing with couverture and decorating to your heart's content.

CREATING SCHOGGI FIGURES
Decorate your own seasonal Easter Bunny. Create colourful chocolate Easter Eggs or a Christmas Boot, filled with luxurious chocolates made by your own fair hands.

SCHOGGI BAR POURING
Pour, decorate and package your own chocolate bars to your heart’s content – the sky’s the limit when it comes to your imagination.

HIGH HEELS COURSE
The high heel shoe of your dreams. With delicate flourishes and lacy bits? With clean lines and no frilly bits? We can help you create the life-size high heel shoe of your dreams using the finest Swiss chocolate.

CHOCOLATE BAR COURSE
Take part in our unique chocolate bar course and pour and decorate your own chocolate bars exactly the way you want them.

COOKIE COURSE
Take part in our cookie course and create your own edible cookie table cards – or anything else for that matter – using royal icing and a whole host of other decorations.

CUPCAKES COURSE
You’re dreaming of cupcakes as beautiful as... well, as beautiful as no one has ever made before? In our cupcakes course, we’ll teach you and your friends everything you need to know about being a cupcake baker and decorator pro!

data.name: Paint like Paul Klee
data.abstract: A creative workshop combined with a tour of the current exhibition in the Zentrum Paul Klee promotes imagination and communication within the team.
data.description:
The professional infrastructure of the Zentrum Paul Klee provides the perfect setting for finding creative ways of dealing with the wide variety of challenges in a company. 

Individually tailored to customer requirements, the teamwork in the Creaviva Atelier facilitates new insights, which contribute to a company’s long-term success. We are happy to advise our customers personally, thus combining creativity in the atelier, communication in the seminar room, and culinary skills in the Schöngrün restaurant.

data.name: Visit the Alphorn factory
data.abstract: Guided tour of the alphorn factory in Habkern
data.description:
The production of this Swiss national symbol is new to Habkern. The Alphornshop is open daily and can be visited by the public. Guided group tours of the workshop are offered upon request. 

Duration: 2h 
Number of participants: 1-25
Languages: German, English, French

data.name: Mule Trekking
data.abstract: Set off on an exciting donkey trek with your children. It's great fun for the entire family!
data.description: With your feet off the ground on the back of a donkey, or simply permitting a donkey to free you of a heavy backpack, donkey trekking in the beautiful alpine landscapes around Davos is an out-of-the-ordinary pleasure for adults as well as children. Half-day tours as well as multi-day tours are possible too.

data.name: Bierhübeli
data.abstract: Regular popular live acts and dance parties guarantee for a great time at this renowned cultural joint, while you relax over a drink in the lounge.
data.description:
Hall. Every week popular live acts and dance parties. The stage disappears behind a velvet curtain, when it is not used. On one side and in the back this big hall has a balcony with a good view of the stage.

Lounge. Whether you want to enjoy a cocktail in quiet before the concert or get away for a moment of peace, when the party in the big hall is in full swing. The Bierhübeli lounge is a suitable place to retreat and guarantees good vibrations! Admission is free.

Beer garden. In the beer garden under beautiful chestnut trees you can enjoy ice-cold beer and excellent snacks: From weisswurst with pretzels and cheese salad to spare ribs and home-made apple pie.

data.name: Mahogany Hall
data.abstract: Oldest music club in town mainly with jazz, blues, soul, rock, funk and reggae concerts. Near BärenPark.
data.description:
The Mahogany Hall was founded in 1968 together with the Longstreet Jazzclub. At the beginning oldtime jazz concerts of the house orchester were performed, but over time those were complemented by regional jazz formations and folkbands.

Today, thanks to its special club atmosphere the Mahogany Hall is a favorite for the performing well-known artists as well as newcomers out of a large number of areas, who describe their performance there as a highlight in their tour plan.

Mahogany Hall can be rented out for special birthdays, wedding celebrations or also company events. Terrific view from the terrace to the lower old town.

data.name: A stroll through the vineyards
data.abstract: Take a leisurely walk to explore the vineyards surrounding Morges, and round off the feast for your eyes with one for your palate at the idyllic Ermitage des Ravet.
data.description:
Fabulous views of the two symbols of this region – the majestic castle of Vufflens and the lake of Geneva with its brilliant blue and green hues – accompany your stroll through the vineyards. After the walk, you receive a warm welcome at the gourmet restaurant Ermitage des Ravet. A father and his son are the chefs at the former winegrower’s house which was tastefully refurbished. Mother and daughter take care of their guests’ wellbeing. Why not spend the night at the adjoining hotel?
A smartphone and the Vaud:Guide app turn the walk into a playful, informative experience. Two routes are available which can be chosen individually or consecutively. 

No. 1: Walk through the vineyards
 * 4.8 km in the vineyards of Morges
 * approx. 3 h walking time 

No. 2: Walk in the town of Morges
 * 1.5 km in the town of Morges
 * approx. 1.5 h walking time

data.name: The Cheese Train
data.abstract: Rustic and authentic! Enjoy an unforgettable day in Pays-d'Enhaut.
data.description:
The day begins with a ride on a GoldenPass-MOB scenic train from Montreux or Zweisimmen. In Château-d’Oex, you will discover the secrets of making a Swiss alpine cheese.
At the restaurant Le Chalet, the farmer makes one “Le Chalet Bio” cheese per day from 400 litres of fresh milk in the traditional way – over a wood fire. Enjoy your delicious fondue in this rustic setting. Above the restaurant on the first floor, you will find the GoldenPass MOB trains miniature railway, which will make the eyes of big and small visitors shine brightly. Lastly, a “souvenir bag” will be given to you in the restaurant to remember this truly Swiss experience. In the afternoon visit the Musée du Pays-d'Enhaut where you can discover the treasures of local crafts and the art of paper-cutting.

The return time to your starting point or the onward journey on the GoldenPass MOB trains is at your free choice. Reserving a seat for this is recommended but not included in the price.

FACTS
Route: Montreux/Zweisimmen – Château d’Oex – Montreux/Zweisimmen
Duration: approx. 4 h 

TIMETABLE
The Cheese Train runs from January to October.TICKET
This route is fully covered by the Swiss Travel Pass (Flex) and GA travelcard.
Book tickets [https://www.myswitzerland.com/planning/transport-accommodation/tickets-public-transport/]

address.name: Compagnie du Chemin de Fer Montreux Oberland bernois SA

data.name: GoldenPass Express
data.abstract: The GoldenPass Express redefines the travel experience between Interlaken and Montreux.
data.description:
SEAMLESS TRAVEL EXPERIENCE
The GoldenPass Express provides a seamless and even more comfortable travel experience on one of Switzerland’s most picturesque train routes. The panoramic train will connect Interlaken with Montreux up to four times a day, offering uninterrupted views of the breathtaking panorama.PRESTIGE
The travel class “Prestige” is the centrepiece of the train. It offers everything you would expect from an unforgettable train journey: plenty of privacy, maximum comfort in a small compartment, and an exceptional culinary offering.

Make yourself comfortable on the luxurious and heated leather seats, which can be rotated 180 degrees upon request. The travel class is also elevated by 40 cm compared to the other travel classes, offering you an even better view of the fascinating scenery.

CULINARY DELIGHTS ON THE GOLDENPASS EXPRESS
Local and international delicacies can be ordered in advance, ensuring a perfect start to an exciting journey. For example, how about a glass of champagne and a portion of the finest caviar from Frutigen in Switzerland?

If you prefer to pamper your palate with regional delicacies, you won’t be disappointed with a traditional apéro-plate or a vegetarian alternative. While champagne and caviar are served exclusively in “Prestige” and 1st class, you can enjoy selected dishes from the small but exquisite menu in all travel classes.

WORLD-FAMOUS PLACES, THREE REGIONS
The journey on the GoldenPass Express is like a foray through Switzerland. The trip starts in picturesque Interlaken and continues via Gstaad, Château-d’Oex and Montbovon to Montreux, the journey’s final stop. Of course, you can also start your trip in Montreux.

Interlaken is a great base for numerous activities and boasts incredible views of Eiger, Mönch and Jungfrau. Luxurious Gstaad is known for its charming chalets and is a favourite holiday spot among stars and winter sports enthusiasts alike. Château-d’Oex is known for its hot air balloons and, with a little luck, you might spot one aloft. Montreux, of course, is home to the annual Montreux Jazz Festival [https://www.montreuxjazzfestival.com/en/].


SWISSNESS
The GoldenPass Express is a world-first and a Swiss masterstroke. After all, the idea of connecting Interlaken and Montreux without needing to change trains originated more than 100 years ago. The project never materialised, however, because of the different track gauges of the respective sections of the line. But this seemingly impossible challenge could now be solved by an ingenious invention: adjustable bogies.
GOLDENPASS EXPRESS TIMETABLE


The current timetable as well as additional information can be found here [https://www.gpx.swiss/en/pages/timetable].


RESERVATIONS AND SURCHARGES
Due to limited seating capacity, reservations are mandatory in “Prestige” (CHF 49) and strongly recommended for 1st and 2nd class travel. This is in addition to a valid ticket for the selected travel class.

The only thing you might find disappointing? The entire trip lasts just 3 hours 15 minutes. With those stunning views and unrivalled comfort, the journey is just as spectacular as the destination.


SWISS TRAVEL PASS
This route is fully included in the Swiss Travel Pass (Flex) / GA Travelcard, though seat reservations must be paid for separately. 
Book tickets [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/planning/transport-accommodation/tickets-public-transport/]

data.name: Herzschlaufe Seetal
data.abstract: The tour «Herzschlaufe Seetal» leads from Eschenbach LU to Lenzburg and back for over nearly 120 km, all this away from traffic. The attractive E-bike route can be done in two days and shows an unfamiliar area of the cantons of Aargau and Lucerne.
data.description:
Start of tour:Eschenbach LU End of tour:Eschenbach LU Number of stages:2Length:114 km Asphalted:76 km Natural surface:38 km Demanding physical fitness:difficult Difference in altitude:↑ 2150 m
↓ 2150 m 
During the first day of the trip, the «Herzschlaufe Seetal» passes the monastery Eschenbach right after the beginning. The route then changes into small paths, where cyclists are surrounded by high trunk cultures. Soon it is possible to get to the »Johanniterkommende Hohenrain«, with stunning views over the Alps and Lake Baldegg.

The route becomes steeper and steeper and slowly leads over the Lindenberg. On top of the secluded plateau, the Horben Castle with chapel and farm suprises the guests. After a brief passage in the forest, the height route begins. Cyclists will go through pretty villages and generous landscape and enjoy the view of Lake Hallwil.

Again they will be surprised by a castle (Hilfikon), which traps visitors with its noble sphere in an unexpected place. Trough a forest you'll get to Seengen and will soon see the great moated castle Hallwyl. You'll only get a glimpse of the tourist hustle, then the route disappears in the cozy forest and follows the lively Aabach river direction Lenzburg.

Starting from proud city of Lenzburg and the neighboring Staufen, the quiet path finds a loophole just after Seon, which results in a magical forest. At the end of the wood the Liebegg castle appears as if in a dream. The track once again disappears in the green of the Aargau area and reappears only on the top of Bööler, where you overlook the vast land.

A schuss leads to Schlossrued. Thereafter, a ridge has to be climbed again, where you'll cycle for long periods without seeing villages or traffic. Only in Beromünster you'll be back to known locations and will be able to enjoy the magnificent Landflecklein.

The route leads back away from traffic and to the golf court Sempachersee, where you can take a break and enjoy the magnificent views of Mount Pilatus. Shortly afterwards, the loop joins the regional routes 94 and 99 (Heart Route). From here it is only a short hop to Eschenbach.
www.herzschlaufe-seetal.ch [http://www.herzschlaufe-seetal.ch/]

data.name: Schwellenmätteli
data.abstract: The Schwellenmätteli’s terrace virtually floats over the Aare River. You have the feeling that you’re sitting in the middle of the water with it rushing and splashing wonderfully all around you. Local specialities are served here. They are prepared with a playful touch and a noticeable passion for the South, which goes perfectly with the scenery.

data.name: ViaRomana - Myth and reality of the Roman roads
data.abstract: Route: Geneva - Lausanne - Orbe - Avenches - Solothurn - Augst
data.description:
Almost two-thousand years after its prime the fascination of Roman building techniques and culture lives on. Thanks to new excavations and research it has become much easier to separate myth from reality. Along idyllic Roman roads, real and imagined, the ViaRomana links the most important Roman sites in Switzerland. It spells out the Roman culture with all its facets. 

In eleven legs accomplished in eleven days, the ViaRomana path leads from Geneva to Augst via the Three-Lakes region. And between Avenches and Augst you get to see genuine Roman roads (Grosse Moos arch) as well as tracks from the early New Age, long thought to be Roman (St. Wolfgang, Oberer Hauenstein).

data.name: Heiliggeistkirche (Holy Spirit Church)
data.description: The Heiliggeistkirche was built by Niklaus Schiltknecht, the town's master mason, and inaugurated in 1729. It is located on the site of what was previously known as the hospital church. The Heiliggeistkirche is considered to be the most beautiful Protestant baroque church in Switzerland. Richly furnished, the interior is dominated by fourteen freestanding sandstone columns and the pulpit in the northern part of the nave.

data.name: Going with the flow – naturally
data.abstract: The Aare is the longest river lying entirely within Switzerland. Between Biel and Solothurn, it offers perfect conditions for canoeists.
data.description:
The stork colony at Altreu and the extensive forests and pretty villages along the river bank make the stretch of the Aare below Biel the perfect playground for canoe fans. Without any great exertion, canoeists are carried to Solothurn, a Baroque city, blending French charm and Italian grandeur, that is one of the most beautiful in Switzerland.
CANOE TIP: AARE CANOEING
For all information on the SwitzerlandMobility route network: SwitzerlandMobility Canoeing [https://www.schweizmobil.ch/en/canoeing-in-switzerland.html]

data.name: Du Théâtre
data.abstract: Lifestyle is the word. The «DüDü» - as it is lovingly called by the locals - is the most attractive club of Switzerland with a range of innovative and varied events.
data.description:
The place where stylish club events take place. The trendy hip place with bar and lounge is the meeting point for awesome, unforgettable parties. Also the famous and the beautiful are welcomed guests in the club right next to the clock tower (Zytglogge).

Emphasis on lifestyle is placed on the Lounge, where comfortable leather chairs and sofas, a fireplace as well as a glass roof contribute to a special big city atmosphere. Famous DJs present the latest in music and keep the party mood going.

Sipping a cocktail while sitting comfortably in a leather chair or dancing the night away at a trendy party - at the Du Théâtre ("DüDü") everybody is in their element. Furthermore, the Du Théâtre offers an attractive range of Afterwork-Events after 5pm.

data.name: Mesocco Castle Ruins
data.abstract: The castle ruin of Castello Mesocco sits on a rock outcrop in the Italian-speaking southern Mesolcina Valley (Misox).
data.description: It is one of the largest castle fortifications in Switzerland, and from the beginning of the 13th century to 1526 it was the lordly center of the valley. Considered impregnable, the castle was never conquered. Below the castle is the church Santa Maria de Castello, adorned with a well-preserved Late Romanesque fresco cycle.

data.name: Santa Maria del Castello
data.description: The chapel dedicated to St. Mary sits on a hill above Osogna. It was built on the ruins of a medieval castle. Dating back to the 16th century, it was restored in 1972. The winged altar is the work of Ivo Strigel from Memmingen (1494). At its center, St. George and St. Markus are depicted, on the inner sides are the images of the saints Jacob and Wolfgang, on the outer sides Christopher and Anna Metterza.
